CAROLINA, USA (79%); NORTH CAROLINA, USA (79%); NEW YORK, USA (79%); COLORADO,
USA (79%); TEXAS, USA (79%); CALIFORNIA, USA (79%)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%)

LOAD-DATE: July 26, 2015


                   Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company


                              58 of 372 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                              July 26, 2015 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

Terrorism Case Fails, but No One Can Say Why That Happened

BYLINE: By STEPHEN CASTLE

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Foreign Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 1345 words


LONDON --  Ian Cobain, a reporter with The Guardian, is one of very few people
who know why a student arrested by armed British police officers in 2013 was
finally acquitted this year of terrorism charges.

Problem is, he cannot report what he knows. He was allowed to observe much of
the trial, but only under strict conditions intended to keep classified material
secret. His notebooks are being held by Britain's domestic intelligence agency.
And if he writes -- or even talks -- about the reason that the student, Erol
Incedal, 27, was acquitted, Mr. Cobain faces prosecution and possibly jail.

''I know the essence of what was happening,'' Mr. Cobain said, ''but I can't
tell, I can't even talk to my editor about this.''

Having initially gone along reluctantly with the reporting restrictions, a
number of British news organizations are now challenging them in court. And yes,
the challenge itself is being heard under secrecy rules that leave the public
mostly excluded. Were Mr. Cobain to break the law and disclose what he knows
publicly, his prosecution would also take place in secret.

''Not even the Russians do that to journalists,'' Mr. Cobain said, speaking
recently in the cafe of the Royal Courts of Justice in London.

The case is among the latest to highlight the growing debate about the proper
balance between civil liberties and national security in the age of terrorism.
That debate has intensified this year in the United States and across much of
Europe, with nations reflecting on decisions they have made since the Sept. 11
attacks and reacting to more recent developments, from the Charlie Hebdo attacks
in Paris to disclosures in Germany about eavesdropping by the United States
National Security Agency.

In Britain, which recently lost 30 citizens to a terrorist attack in Tunisia,
public support for the intelligence and security agencies is high, according to
opinion surveys, and Prime Minister David Cameron has promised to expand their
resources and their ability to monitor electronic communications.

But the Incedal case has focused attention on whether governments are cloaking
too many of their activities in national security classifications, insulating
themselves from public debate and accountability for mistakes or collusion with
suspects.

''It's hard to know quite who is being protected in all this,'' said David
Davis, a lawmaker from the governing Conservative Party and a former minister.

''The implication is that this is more about the embarrassment of the agencies
than it is about real questions of national security,'' he added.

Sean O'Neill, a reporter with The Times of London who also attended the secret
hearings, said he believes that the government's desire to keep some of the
trial evidence secret was legitimate, but that this could have been done under
normal rules allowing parts of trials to be held behind closed doors.

Instead, the conduct of the Incedal case demonstrated an ''obsession with
secrecy'' at a time when there is growing debate on the oversight of
intelligence agencies, Mr. O'Neill said.

''There is a refusenik factor in these organizations which thinks 'anything we
give will undermine us, and therefore undermine national security,' '' he said.

The result is that, as things stand, public knowledge about one of Britain's
biggest recent terrorism trials is a patchwork of partial truths and unanswered
questions.

In the parts of the proceedings that were open, jurors heard that Mr. Incedal
traveled to Syria, met a fighter known as Ahmed and discussed terrorist attacks.

In September 2013, Mr. Incedal, who was born in Turkey but lived in London, was
stopped by the police for speeding, and his car was searched. A slip of paper
found in a glasses case contained the address of a property owned by Tony Blair,
a former prime minister.

While he was detained, Mr. Incedal's car was bugged, and a listening device
recorded him talking about buying a gun.

Then came the dramatic arrest by armed police officers when Mr. Incedal was
stopped while driving with a friend, Mounir Rarmoul-Bouhadjar, near Tower Bridge
in central London, and the tires of his Mercedes were shot out. The police found
a memory card with instructions on assembling a bomb in Mr. Incedal's phone
case.

After his first trial last year, Mr. Incedal was convicted of possessing the
bomb-making guide, and was sentenced to 42 months in jail. Mr. Rarmoul-Bouhadjar
was jailed, too, after admitting to having a similar manual. But a jury could
not agree on whether to convict Mr. Incedal of broader terrorism offenses.

After a retrial, Mr. Incedal was acquitted in March, but the reasons remain
unknown to the public.

Mr. Incedal argued in open court that he wanted a gun to protect himself as he
was planning to deal in drugs, and that he had a ''reasonable excuse'' for
having the bomb-making manual. Again, what that excuse was is not clear.

Even these scraps of information are more than the authorities wanted made
public. Initially, prosecutors argued that they might not be able to bring the
case to court unless it was held in complete secrecy.

But after an appeal by news organizations last year, a strange middle way
emerged: Some of the trial was held in public, some in secret, and the rest in a
kind of no man's land.

Ten reporters, including Mr. Cobain and Mr. O'Neill, were admitted to these
segments of the trial on the condition that they published nothing from the
semi-secret sessions and that, at the end of each day, their reporters'
notebooks were locked in a safe.

The notebooks are now being held by MI5, Britain's domestic intelligence service
-- a fact that has been reported by the British news media and is not denied by
the government, although it will not comment officially.

In going along with the reporting restrictions a year ago, the 10 news
organizations accredited to the trial may have believed -- incorrectly as it
proved -- that the secrecy would be lifted at the end of proceedings. Although
not all of the news organizations covered every phase of the trial, no media
group refused to attend on principle. Mr. Cobain says he now has ''real
reservations'' about having gone along with the process, but, of course, cannot
explain why.

In a statement, the Crown Prosecution Service said that the case ''touched on
important issues which related to national security.''

''Some evidence has already been made public as it was dealt with in open
court,'' the statement said. ''We are working to identify evidence heard during
the closed proceedings which could be placed in the public domain.''

''The extent to which further evidence can go into the public domain will
ultimately be a decision for the judge.''

Many are not convinced. ''How is the public to evaluate the state's actions if
the media cannot report on it?'' said Cian C. Murphy, a legal expert at King's
College London.

''In constitutional terms, secrecy is anathema to the rule of law because legal
and political accountability is impossible without transparency,'' he said. ''If
errors are made, they must be brought to light -- but there is little incentive
for the prosecution, intelligence agencies or government departments to
acquiesce when they can invoke national security to ensure secrecy.''

Critics contend that such secrecy risks eroding not only civil liberties, but
ultimately the effectiveness of the intelligence agencies, too.

''The more secret the organization is, the more inefficient it tends to be,''
Mr. Davis said. ''It's unwise to think of them as a bunch of hyperefficient
James Bonds. They probably aren't.''

''The truth is,'' he added, ''that there is no such thing as secret justice. If
it's secret, it's not justice.''

The appeal against the reporting restrictions has now been adjourned until the
autumn, but in one public session this month, Lord Chief Justice John Thomas
acknowledged that there were ''really difficult constitutional issues'' at
stake.

A few minutes later, those reporters without special permission to attend were
politely asked to leave.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/26/world/europe/a-terrorism-case-in-britain-ends-
in-acquittal-but-no-one-can-say-why.html

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Are There Literary Uses for Boredom?

BYLINE: By RIVKA GALCHEN and ADAM KIRSCH

SECTION: Section BR; Column 0; Book Review Desk; BOOKENDS; Pg. 27

LENGTH: 1461 words


Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books.
This week, Rivka Galchen and Adam Kirsch discuss whether boring books might
serve an interesting purpose.

By Rivka Galchen

Boredom is a kind of meditation. To be bored is, for a spell, to not let the
noise out there get in.

Harry is a dirty dog.

Or is he?

He's a white dog with black spots who doesn't like to take a bath. He runs away
from home! What fun he has going around town, getting covered in dirt and soot
and coal, so that he becomes a black dog with white spots. Eventually Harry gets
a bit hungry and tired. When he returns to his house, his family doesn't
recognize him. They watch him do his tricks, then turn their backs and walk
away. Harry is so sad. Until he thinks to run upstairs, and take a bath, and is
again recognized, and welcomed home with love.

I have read ''Harry the Dirty Dog'' (by Gene Zion, with pictures by Margaret
Bloy Graham) approximately three times a day, most days, for about 16 months,
which, in a rough estimate, translates into 1,440 readings. At times, the
tension as to what will happen with Harry does fall slack. But at other times it
doesn't. Boredom bores a hole right over to the antipodes of boring, and I
sometimes find myself, even at moments when I am liberated from this ritual of
rereading, still thinking about Harry.

On occasion, when I turn the page to see Harry performing his old tricks,
rolling over and playing dead, only to find his skeptical family shaking their
heads and walking away -- ''Oh no, it couldn't be Harry,'' they say -- I feel an
intensity of family feeling I associate more with news stories about soldiers
telling their families via Skype that they are gay. Is this just an illustrated
board book, or is it more like a Greek tragedy, hinging on a drama of
recognition? Is it really possible that they don't recognize Harry? Or do they
just refuse to recognize him as he has deviated from the family value of
.â[#x20ac][#x2c6].â[#x20ac][#x2c6]. cleanliness?

I admit I don't always make it to the end of the drama. Sometimes my
Â­co-traveler through the book is filled with an urgent need to turn back the
pages and re-experience, on Page 3, the apples. On Page 12, the ladder. On Page
20, sometimes she kisses the sad Harry. Sometimes not. Sometimes I am aware that
my co-traveler is the most interesting person I know. Sometimes I am not.

At least one aspect of boredom is a failure of perception. We can never
legitimately be bored by the world. Moss, under a microscope, exceeds our
imaginative and intellectual capacities. There is no boredom out there. There is
only boredom in here, in the mind.

Yet to be bored is not just a failing. Centuries of artists and writers and
philosophers who have praised boredom (and its genteel cousin, idleness) were
probably not simply conspiring to justify lying around on a sofa for more hours
than seem obviously necessary. (Though, maybe.) Boredom is a kind of meditation.
To be bored is, for a spell, to not let the noise out there get in. Which is
also a way of letting something happen in the meager, but essential, in here. To
never be bored would be to never be prompted to rupture the boredom. So even as
boredom is a kind of failure of perception, it also restores perception. Harry
was always Harry, but his family could no longer see that. ''He started to do
all his old, clever tricks. He flip-flopped and he flop-flipped. He rolled over
and played dead. .â[#x20ac][#x2c6].â[#x20ac][#x2c6]. But everyone shook their
heads.''

Often in recognition scenes, someone who had been believed by a character to be
dead is revealed as still alive. We see this with Viola and Sebastian in
Shakespeare's ''Twelfth Night,'' with Joseph in the Bible story of his coat of
many colors. The recognition, in these stories, is also a kind of resurrection.
In boredom, it is the world that had appeared to be dead and that reveals itself
as new, as miraculously returned. ''He jumped into the bathtub and sat up
begging, with the scrubbing brush in his mouth, a trick he certainly had never
done before.'' After the bath, Harry's family ''sees'' him again. Harry's bath
worked, ''like magic.'' Harry then sleeps, at home, and has happy dreams.

Rivka Galchen is a recipient of a William J. Saroyan International Prize for
Fiction, a Rona Jaffe Foundation Writers' Award and a Berlin Prize, among other
distinctions. Her fiction and nonfiction have appeared in numerous publications,
including Harper's and The New Yorker, which selected her for their list of ''20
Under 40'' American fiction writers in 2010. Her debut novel, the critically
acclaimed ''Atmospheric Disturbances,'' was published in 2008. Her second book,
a story collection titled ''American Innovations,'' was published in May.

â--+ â--+ â--+

By Adam Kirsch

Some of the most acclaimed recent books contain long stretches in which barely
anything happens.

There's no book so beloved that someone, somewhere, hasn't found it unreadably
boring. On Goodreads, in response to the question ''What's the most boring book
you've ever read?,'' it's a given that the answers will include dense and
intimidating volumes like ''Moby-Dick.'' But readers have also apparently been
bored by a number of books that in their time were considered thrilling and
shocking -- ''Lolita,'' ''The Catcher in the Rye,'' even an adventure tale like
''Around the World in Eighty Days'' (''Felt like I was reading it for 80
days'').

Often, it is the books enjoying the most official honor -- the syllabus
standbys, the anthology all-stars -- that provide readers with their first
experience of literary boredom. Partly that is because the classroom is seldom
the best setting for encountering works of literature, which after all were not
written to educate, but to seduce. Poetry, Philip Larkin wrote, should rely on
cash customers -- those who are willing to actually put down money in the
expectation of getting something worthwhile, some genuine pleasure, in return.
When this hedonistic motive is eliminated, when seduction turns into obligation,
it's no wonder that readerly appetite cools to mere dutifulness, which is only a
half-step from outright boredom.

But it's not only a sense of obligation that can make the classics boring. A
classic is by definition a book from another time, and the conventions of the
past stand between it and us like a series of locked doors. To learn how to take
pleasure in the art of the past -- and this is true of music and painting, as
much as of literature -- usually means passing through an initial period of
boredom, just as playing the piano requires learning scales before sonatas. The
treasures that lie on the other side of boredom must, at first, be taken on
faith, which is why a serious reader is always a humble one, ready to distrust
his or her own first impression and rely on the consensus of the past.

Boredom, in other words, is usually a form of misreading; or as parents warn
their children, only boring people get bored. But what if an author seems to be
trying to bore us on purpose? Some of the most acclaimed books of recent years
-- I'm thinking in particular of Roberto BolaÃ±o's ''2666'' and Karl Ove
Knausgaard's ''My Struggle'' -- contain long stretches in which barely anything
happens: BolaÃ±o will spend 50 pages listing murder victims, or Knausgaard the
same amount of space recounting a walk to a high school party. At such moments
they seem to have taken too literally W.H. Auden's admonition, in his poem ''The
Novelist,'' that the novelist must ''become the whole of boredom.''

But what feels like boredom, in these cases, might better be described as
aggressive estrangement. Proust describes the way genuine innovation in art
usually strikes us, at first, as mere incompetence, because it refuses to
conform to received aesthetic standards. (The Impressionists, the Cubists, the
Pop artists were all accused of simply not knowing how to paint.) This is not to
say that a boring book is always a clandestine work of genius; but it does
suggest that a certain kind of boredom -- the boredom of incomprehension, rather
than the boredom of overfamiliarity -- should be taken as a challenge. The most
useful question to ask about a boring book is not ''Why is this author
incompetent?'' but ''What is this author trying to do that I don't understand?''
Whether the book in question was published 200 years ago or last week, our
boredom may turn out to be merely the cloak of its splendor.

Adam Kirsch is a columnist for Tablet. He is the author of two collections of
poetry and several other books, including, most recently, ''Why Trilling
Matters.'' In 2010, he won the Roger Shattuck Prize for Criticism.

This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in
print.

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/26/books/review/are-there-literary-uses-for-bored
om.html

Australian Who Says He Was Forced to Help ISIS Is Arrested

BYLINE: By MICHELLE INNIS

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Foreign Desk; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 460 words


SYDNEY, Australia --  A 39-year-old nurse from Melbourne who said he was forced
to work with the Islamic State militant group in Syria was arrested upon
returning to Australia, the authorities said Saturday.

The nurse, Adam Brookman, was arrested Friday night at Sydney's international
airport on a warrant related to what the authorities said was his involvement in
the Syrian conflict, according to the Australian Federal Police. He surrendered
to the authorities in Turkey on Tuesday, the police said in a statement. The
statement did not identify Mr. Brookman by name, but his activities have been
widely reported in the Australian news media.

The police did not say what charges Mr. Brookman might face. But antiterrorism
laws passed last year make it illegal for Australians to be in the Syrian city
of Raqqa, a control center for the Islamic State, without a legitimate reason. A
conviction is punishable by prison sentences of up to 10 years. Providing
material support to a militant group like the Islamic State, which is also known
as ISIS or ISIL, is punishable by harsher sentences.

Mr. Brookman, a convert to Islam, told The Sydney Morning Herald that he went to
Syria to do humanitarian work, but that he was forced to work with the Islamic
State after he was wounded in an airstrike and taken to a hospital controlled by
the group. He said he never took up arms and focused on medical tasks;
eventually, he said, he was able to escape and, later, to cross the border into
Turkey.

The Sydney Morning Herald, citing court documents, reported Saturday that Mr.
Brookman was accused of working as a guard for the militant group. He was flown
in police custody from Sydney to Melbourne, in the state of Victoria, where he
was expected to appear in court on Monday, the newspaper said.

Prime Minister Tony Abbott said Thursday that 120 Australians were fighting on
the side of extremists in Syria and Iraq, and that 160 other Australians
actively supported extremist groups. He said that hundreds of people had been
questioned about their travel plans and that the government had confiscated the
passports of more than 100 Australians to stop them from joining the fighting.

''Australians have been consistently warned that by becoming involved in
overseas conflict they are putting their own lives in mortal danger,'' the
federal police said in a separate statement. ''If there is evidence an
Australian has committed a criminal offense under Australia law while involved
in the conflict in Syria and Iraq, they will be charged and put before the
courts.''

The government is preparing legislation that would allow it to prevent known
terrorists who are dual citizens from returning to Australia by stripping them
of their Australian citizenship.

-worked-with-isis-under-duress.html

Next Rodriguez Milestone Is a Number for the Ages

BYLINE: By BILLY WITZ

SECTION: Section SP; Column 0; Sports Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 1054 words


MINNEAPOLIS --  Alex Rodriguez has joined some exclusive clubs this season. He
now finds himself with Willie Mays, Babe Ruth, Henry Aaron and Barry Bonds as
the only players to have hit 660 home runs, and he became the 29th player to
have 3,000 hits, doing so in striking fashion with a home run.

On Monday, Rodriguez will join another select set: He will turn 40.

''It's a milestone,'' Rodriguez said with a knowing smile.

''Milestone,'' of course, was a loaded word earlier this season when Rodriguez
and the Yankees were wrangling over a $6 million marketing bonus tied to his
climb up the career home run list. (The Yankees, before they reached a
compromise with Rodriguez, had refused to call his accomplishments milestones.)

But Rodriguez's sense of accomplishment this year stems not only from his
bouncing back after seasons of decline and his 2014 suspension but also from his
longevity. Only nine active players are older than Rodriguez, according to the
Elias Sports Bureau, and only two of them are not pitchers: outfielders Ichiro
Suzuki of the Miami Marlins and Torii Hunter of the Minnesota Twins. Only
Hunter, who turned 40 on July 18, is a regular starter.

''Definitely 40 is a big birthday,'' said Rodriguez, who was flying his two
daughters to Arlington, Tex., so they could celebrate along with his teammates.
(The Yankees will open a four-game series against the Rangers there on Monday.)

''I came into the league at 18, so for me the remarkable part is it's been 22
years,'' Rodriguez said. ''That's a long time, and it's gone quickly. When I
start thinking about it like that, it's pretty incredible.''

Publicly, Rodriguez has allowed himself little room for rumination this season,
speaking the lines of a humble servant and not saying anything impolitic, even
during the impasse over the bonus. Perhaps for the first time since heading to
New York in 2004, he has let his bat do all the talking.

He is in the midst of perhaps his best season since 2010, batting .277 with 23
home runs, 58 R.B.I. and an on-base plus slugging percentage of .914. The
Yankees have mirrored his comeback: They sit in first place in the American
League East after missing the playoffs the last two seasons.

Rodriguez has fit well into a clubhouse with many new faces and has won over
some skeptics despite his history with performance-enhancing drugs.

''He's been remarkable,'' General Manager Brian Cashman said. ''Forty is a big
number. Bottom line: Normally you're not in a position to be evaluating
40-year-olds anymore in this game, because they're usually out of the game.''

Despite Rodriguez's initial scorched-earth approach to his suspension --
bringing lawsuits against the Yankees' doctor, Major League Baseball and the
players' union -- he said the year off helped set the stage for this season.

''The time off helped me mentally, physically and emotionally,'' Rodriguez said.
''The time off was a blessing in disguise.''

He added: ''From a physical point of view, it allowed me to rest and fully
recover from some of the injuries I've had over the last several years -- two
hip surgeries, wrist, knees. It allowed me to mend fully and recharge my
batteries and train for the first time in many years for a full season. It also
helped me reorganize my training regimen.''

Rodriguez said he worked on his flexibility and motion more than he had earlier
in his career, using exercises such as Pilates and yoga.

Twins Manager Paul Molitor said the mental task a 40-year-old faced in a young
man's game should not be underestimated. Molitor had one of the finest seasons
of his Hall of Fame career in 1996, when he turned 40. He led the American
League with 225 hits, batted .341 and had a career-high 113 R.B.I. for the
Twins.

''When things don't go well or you have a bad day, the immediate question is, am
I getting to that point, or is this part of the downhill?'' Molitor said. ''You
fight that more than you do when you're younger, but for the guys that rise
above that, they have that intangible.''

Another element of Rodriguez's resurgence has been his change in position. The
Yankees had initially seen Rodriguez as the primary designated hitter, with
other older players, such as first baseman Mark Teixeira and right fielder
Carlos Beltran, sharing the role. The team also planned to use Rodriguez as the
backup first and third baseman.

Rodriguez batted seventh on opening day, but within two weeks he was anchored in
his more familiar third spot. He has not started in the field since May 19.

Taking a former Gold Glove away had the potential to be a touchy subject, like
taking the car keys away from an older relative, but Manager Joe Girardi said
that after about the first month he realized that he could play Rodriguez more
often if he used him only as the designated hitter.

''He bought into the idea pretty quickly,'' Girardi said. ''The results were
there. When there's results, I think it's always easier to buy into an idea or
an opportunity.''

Asked if he still considered himself a position player, Rodriguez laughed.

''No, there's no part of that,'' he said.

''Obviously, anyone who has played the field as long as I have, you get the
feeling of aw,'' Rodriguez said, slumping his shoulders, ''but then you realize
you can really help the team by being a D.H. It's something I'm really
enjoying.''

On Wednesday, Rodriguez clubbed a 453-foot home run off the Baltimore rookie
Kevin Gausman that cleared the bullpens in left-center field at Yankee Stadium.

Moments like that notwithstanding, Rodriguez has still provided occasional
reminders that he is not the spry prodigy of his early years, when he was
reaching the 40-40 club (of home runs and stolen bases) instead of the
40-and-over club.

One of those came Thursday, the day after his long home run, when he hustled
from first on a bases-loaded double by Chase Headley. As Rodriguez reached the
plate, he contorted his body to avoid the catcher's tag and then reached down to
touch home plate with his left hand.

The twisting and the turning were too much. Rodriguez tumbled and rolled over
three times, like a child rolling down a grassy knoll. Rodriguez's teammates
laughed when he returned to the dugout, and he laughed, too.

It was one of the few times this season that he had acted his age.

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/26/sports/baseball/for-alex-rodriguez-its-another
-big-number.html

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

& RECREATION (78%); DRUGS IN SPORTS (72%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (70%)

Desperately Seeking Rambo

BYLINE: By STEVEN KURUTZ

SECTION: Section TR; Column 0; Travel Desk; ROAD TRIP; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 1086 words


When my father heard I would be vacationing in Mexico and planned to rent a car,
he told me, ''Just don't get lost in the desert down there.'' A week later, I
was lost in the desert in Mexico.

This was in Baja California Sur 10 years ago this summer, an unforgettable
anniversary, for not a July passes that I don't recall the experience and
shudder a little, imagining a darker outcome.

Young dudes flying to Baja for sun and sand typically head to Cabo San Lucas,
the Pacific resort town at the tip of the peninsula. My buddy Burk and I
vacationed in La Paz, 90 miles up the coast on the Gulf of California side, a
busy port city with thick traffic and a thermoelectric plant belching pollution.

You might say this was our first of many mistakes. But we'd been warned off Cabo
by the example of Sammy Hagar. The former Van Halen singer owned a nightclub
there called the Cabo Wabo Cantina, where he promoted a lifestyle -- with
accompanying tunes -- based on tequila-fueled idiocy. The place seemed best
avoided.

Burk is my good friend from Penn State, and all our dude-cations in those
post-grad years featured a road trip. We'd rocked and rolled down I-95 to
Carolina beach towns. Somehow we felt ready for off-road Mexico.

On Day 3 in La Paz, with the foldout map I'd brought, I plotted our route: a
half day's drive that would take us north along La Paz Bay, then inland before
looping back to town and our dated but pleasant hotel overlooking the malecón.
The midway point -- the spot where I had us refueling and eating amazingly fresh
fish tacos from a rustic hut -- was a town called San Juan de la Costa. On the
map it existed as a tiny pin dot hugging the water's edge.

We left midmorning. Burk drove our rented Ford compact, while I eyed highway
signs. La Paz proper quickly gave way to south-of-the-border sprawl (farmacias,
Pemex gas stations, mystery businesses housed in low cinder-block buildings),
which gave way to -- nothing. The day was typical of summer in Mexico: hot,
cloudless, blindingly bright. Out our windshield was a perfect Kodachrome image
of desert blankness. Not awesome, John Ford desert, either, but craggy
scrubland.

For 20 miles this continued. Then cliffs rose along the road on our left, and
the rocks became weirdly bleached-looking. Rounding a curve, we saw a village
with buildings the same bleached white. As we got closer, it was clear there
were no cars, no people, no life of any kind. The place was eerily deserted. It
was as if a plague had swept through. The road forward had been ominously
blocked with large rocks.

''Is this San Juan de la Costa?'' I said, nervously.

Burk shrugged. ''You've got the map,'' he said.

We faced a decision: go back the way we came -- drive two hours for nothing,
basically -- or find a way around the roadblock and continue our awesome Baja
adventure. We idled on the highway, debating.

Here I should pause to mention some things we learned later, historical tidbits
that more informed tourists might have found useful.

San Juan de la Costa isn't really a town so much as a phosphate mine. Hurricane
Juliette destroyed the mine in 2001, explaining the apocalyptic emptiness.

Also, superstitious locals apparently avoid this region at the north end of La
Paz Bay because of the Legend of Mechudo. According to the story, a young pearl
diver, Mechudo, spotted a fantastically large pearl and became obsessed with
retrieving it to hoard for himself. He drowned for his greed, and caused the
deaths of the divers who jumped in after him. Campfire stuff, although there's
been a plane crash and several mining deaths in the area. Into this cursed
ground drove two gringos in a teensy Ford.

After some discussion, we regretfully decided to turn back. Or I thought we did,
anyway. Burk suddenly changed course and turned down a dirt road that went
toward the sea and curved north.

''This isn't a good idea,'' I said, repeatedly, increasingly aware of the
remoteness of our location. Finally Burk conceded, and attempted a three-point
turnaround. Given the car's off-road capabilities this was ill advised; our
wheels sunk into the desert floor and spun futilely.

At this point, two things happened, almost instantaneously. I became urgently,
desperately thirsty, as if a sand dune were lodged in my throat, and discovered
between us we had only half a bottle of agua. And a bird of prey appeared and
began slowly circling overhead.

There's this thing young men do; they fantasize about finding themselves in
perilous situations. It comes from a desire to find out what you are made of, a
belief you will be Rambo in a crisis. Well, I found out who I am in a crisis:
not Rambo but a frightened jerk. I began to panic and lash out at the same time.
We'll be robbed and murdered by narco-bandits! I screamed. The rental car --
secured with my credit card -- will be picked apart by scrappers, its metal
carcass left to rot in the desert like us! I worked up a mighty thirst insulting
and lecturing.

Whether remorseful or just embarrassed for me, Burk stayed calm and said he'd
get the car unstuck, no problem. He opened the trunk, took out the jack and
tried to raise the wheels. Which might have worked had the car not been on sand.
By now I was apoplectic. Still, my solution was no less delusional. I grabbed
one of the white hotel towels we'd taken in case we went swimming, draped it
around my head turban-style and, like Chevy Chase in ''National Lampoon's
Vacation,'' set off under the scorching noonday sun to walk the 30 miles back to
La Paz.

For my continued existence I owe Miguel. For all I know, he was a guardian angel
disguised as a fisherman wearing a Dodgers T-shirt.

He was sitting under a thatch-roofed lean-to, about half a mile south and more
toward the sea from our marooned car. We had missed the place coming in, but now
I went to it like an oasis. Miguel was in there with his boy, both of them
catching shade. Burk trailed in after me, and redeemed himself by using
primitive, high school Spanish to communicate our predicament: ''Mi carro son
malo.''

We all walked to the car, where it was Miguel who became Rambo, stuffing dried
sagebrush under the wheels for traction, finding a length of wire fencing out of
nowhere. He couldn't get the car free, either. But eventually, a guy came along
in a truck, and the wire became a towline.

Seeing our car moving freely and back on pavement, Burk and I laughed the
laughter of grateful idiots and thanked our rescuers.

The day next day we drove to Cabo.

ne-wrong.html

                              Late Edition - Final

Mike Hale on the Emmy Awards 2015: Predictions, Wishes and What-Ifs

BYLINE: By MIKE HALE

SECTION: Section AR; Column 0; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 1498 words


Mike Hale, one of the TV critics for The New York Times, shares his opinions on
this year's Emmy Awards, which will be hosted by Andy Samberg on Sept. 20 on
Fox.

Outstanding Drama Series

''Better Call Saul'' (AMC) ''Downton Abbey'' (PBS) ''Game of Thrones'' (HBO)
''Homeland'' (Showtime) ''House of Cards'' (Netflix) ''Mad Men'' (AMC) ''Orange
Is the New Black'' (Netflix)

Will win: ''Mad Men''Should win: ''Homeland''Should have been nominated: ''The
Americans''

By putting the focus back on suspense, ''Homeland" rebounded to somewhere near
its first-season heights. But ''The Americans,'' in its third season, continued
to be the best drama on television. Other shows better than some (or all) of the
nominees in this category included ''Empire,'' ''Happy Valley,'' ''Justified,''
''The Knick,'' ''The Missing'' and ''Nashville.''

Outstanding Comedy Series

''Louie'' (FX)''Modern Family'' (ABC)''Parks and Recreation'' (NBC)''Silicon
Valley'' (HBO)''Transparent'' (Amazon)''Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt''
(Netflix)''Veep'' (HBO)

Will win: ''Modern Family''Should win: ''Louie''Should have been nominated:
''Broad City''

It's a sign of the times that a comedy as dark and distinctive as ''Louie'' can
be nominated for an Emmy, but it would still be a surprise if it won. Less
surprising would be a breakthrough by ''Veep.''

Lead Actress, Drama

Claire Danes, ''Homeland''Viola Davis, ''How to Get Away With Murder''Taraji P.
Henson, ''Empire''Tatiana Maslany, ''Orphan Black''Elisabeth Moss, ''Mad
Men''Robin Wright, ''House of Cards''

Will win: Viola DavisShould win: Taraji P. HensonShould have been nominated:
Keri Russell, ''The Americans''

Ms. Davis was very good; Ms. Henson was better; Ms. Russell, for the third
season in a row, was best. Also deserving: Eva Green for ''Penny Dreadful'';
Katey Sagal for ''Sons of Anarchy.''

Lead Actor, Drama

Kyle Chandler, ''Bloodline''Jeff Daniels, ''The Newsroom''Jon Hamm, ''Mad
Men''Bob Odenkirk, ''Better Call Saul''Liev Schreiber, ''Ray Donovan''Kevin
Spacey, ''House of Cards''

Will win: Jon HammShould win: Kyle ChandlerShould have been nominated: Matthew
Rhys, ''The Americans''

Mr. Chandler brings the same quiet authority to Netflix's ''Bloodline'' that he
did to ''Friday Night Lights,'' but Mr. Hamm is an overwhelming favorite for his
final season as Don Draper. In addition to Mr. Rhys, others that deserved
nominations are Clive Owen for ''The Knick'' and Michael Emerson for ''Person of
Interest.''

Lead Actress, Comedy

Edie Falco, ''Nurse Jackie''Lisa Kudrow, ''The Comeback''Julia Louis-Dreyfus,
''Veep''Amy Poehler, ''Parks and Recreation''Amy Schumer, ''Inside Amy
Schumer''Lily Tomlin, ''Grace and Frankie''

Will win: Julia Louis-DreyfusShould win; Edie FalcoShould have been nominated:
Kristen Schaal, ''The Last Man on Earth''

Ms. Falco, who won this category back in 2010 in her show's second season, was
painfully honest and funny throughout its seven-season run. But Ms.
Louis-Dreyfus owns the category; a victory would be her fourth in a row.

Lead Actor, Comedy

Anthony Anderson, ''black-ish''Louis C.K., ''Louie''Don Cheadle, ''House of
Lies''Will Forte, ''The Last Man on Earth''Matt LeBlanc, ''Episodes''William H.
Macy, ''Shameless''Jeffrey Tambor, ''Transparent''

Will win: Jeffrey TamborShould win: Jeffrey TamborShould have been nominated:
Josh Gad, ''The Comedians''

Mr. Gad's brilliant performance as himself, if he were the neurotic,
self-obsessed, irritable second banana to Billy Crystal on a mediocre
sketch-comedy show, made ''The Comedians'' much better than it deserved to be.

Supporting Actress, Drama

Joanne Froggatt, ''Downton Abbey''Lena Headey, ''Game of Thrones''Emilia Clarke,
''Game of Thrones''Christine Baranski, ''The Good Wife''Christina Hendricks,
''Mad Men''Uzo Aduba, ''Orange Is the New Black''

Will win: Christina HendricksShould win: Christine BaranskiShould have been
nominated: Laila Robins, ''Homeland''

''The Good Wife'' didn't give Ms. Baranski much to do this past season, but
whenever it did, she was typically superb.

Supporting Actor, Drama

Jonathan Banks, ''Better Call Saul''Ben Mendelsohn, ''Bloodline''Jim Carter,
''Downton Abbey''Peter Dinklage, ''Game of Thrones''Alan Cumming, ''The Good
Wife''Michael Kelly, ''House of Cards''

Will win: Jonathan BanksShould win: Peter DinklageShould have been nominated:
Nick Searcy, ''Justified''

Mr. Searcy's avuncular but capable chief deputy marshal was a key figure
throughout the six seasons of ''Justified.'' No other category is as rich in
possible nominees: Frank Langella in ''The Americans,'' Mandy Patinkin in
''Homeland,'' Andre Holland in ''The Knick,'' Toby Huss in ''Halt and Catch
Fire,'' Stanley Tucci in ''Fortitude,'' Rory Kinnear in ''Penny Dreadful'' and
Vondie Curtis-Hall in ''Daredevil,'' to name a few.

Supporting Actress, Comedy

Mayim Bialik, ''The Big Bang Theory''Niecy Nash, ''Getting On''Julie Bowen,
''Modern Family''Allison Janney, ''Mom''Kate McKinnon, ''Saturday Night
Live''Gaby Hoffmann, ''Transparent''Jane Krakowski, ''Unbreakable Kimmy
Schmidt''Anna Chlumsky, ''Veep''

Will win: Allison JanneyShould win: Allison JanneyShould have been nominated:
Stephanie Weir, ''The Comedians''

Ms. Janney, as we've come to expect, gives a clinic in timing, control and cool
professionalism. Ms. Weir goes the other direction, reveling in discomfort and
barely suppressed hysteria.

Supporting Actor, Comedy

Andre Braugher, ''Brooklyn Nine-Nine''Adam Driver, ''Girls''Keegan-Michael Key,
''Key & Peele''Ty Burrell, ''Modern Family''Tituss Burgess, ''Unbreakable Kimmy
Schmidt''Tony Hale, ''Veep''

Will win: Tituss BurgessShould win: Keegan-Michael KeyShould have been
nominated: Stephen Tobolowsky, ''Big Time in Hollywood, FL''

Mr. Key is an odd fit in this category, but the sketch comedy format of ''Key &
Peele'' shows off his amazing range. Mr. Tobolowsky, one of the most reliably
funny character actors in the business, brings his special brand of exasperation
to ''Big Time'' (he's also hilarious as a high school principal on ABC's ''The
Goldbergs'' ).

Best Limited Series

''American Crime'' (ABC)''American Horror Story: Freak Show'' (FX)''Olive
Kitteridge'' (HBO)''The Honorable Woman'' (Sundance)''Wolf Hall'' (PBS)

Will win: ''Olive Kitteridge''Should win: ''Wolf Hall''Should have been
nominated; ''One Child'' (Sundance)

''Wolf Hall'' is the best of a tepid bunch in this category.

Outstanding Television Movie

''Agatha Christie's Poirot: Poirot's Last Case'' (PBS)''Bessie'' (HBO)''Grace of
Monaco'' (Lifetime)''Hello Ladies: The Movie'' (HBO)''Killing Jesus'' (National
Geographic Channel)''Nightingale'' (HBO)

Will win: ''Bessie''Should win: ''Hello Ladies: The Movie''Should have been
nominated: ''A Poet in New York''

BBC America's ''Poet in New York'' featured a terrific performance by Tom
Hollander as Dylan Thomas. If it had been on HBO it would have been a shoo-in
for a nomination.

Animated Program

''Archer'' (FX)''Bob's Burgers'' (Fox)''Over the Garden Wall'' (Cartoon
Network)''The Simpsons'' (Fox)''South Park'' (Comedy Central)

Will win: ''Bob's Burgers''Should win: ''Bob's Burgers''Should have been
nominated: ''Star vs. the Forces of Evil'' (Disney XD)

''Bob's Burgers'' would have to buck recent history: No show has repeated in
this category since ''South Park'' in 2008. If that trend continues, look for
''Archer'' to win.

Outstanding Reality Competition Show

''The Amazing Race'' (CBS)''Dancing With the Stars'' (ABC)''Project Runway''
(Lifetime)''So You Think You Can Dance'' (Fox)''Top Chef'' (Bravo)''The Voice''
(NBC)

Will win: ''The Amazing Race''Should win: ''The Voice''Should have been
nominated: ''Face-Off'' (Syfy)

''The Voice'' is the most entertaining of the big competition shows, but ''The
Amazing Race'' has won 10 times in the category's 12 years of existence,
including last year.

Outstanding Variety Series

''The Colbert Report'' (Comedy Central)''The Daily Show With Jon Stewart''
(Comedy Central)''Jimmy Kimmel Live'' (ABC)''Last Week Tonight'' (HBO)''Late
Show With David Letterman'' (CBS)''The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon''
(NBC)

Will win: ''Late Show With David Letterman''Should win: ''The Colbert
Report''Should have been nominated: ''The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson''
(CBS)

The tide of good will generated by Mr. Letterman's retirement from the ''Late
Show'' should carry him to victory over his successor, Stephen Colbert.

Outstanding Variety Sketch Series

''Drunk History'' (Comedy Central)''Inside Amy Schumer'' (Comedy Central)''Key &
Peele'' (Comedy Central)''Portlandia'' (IFC)''Saturday Night Live'' (NBC)

Will win: ''Inside Amy Schumer''Should win: ''Inside Amy Schumer''Should have
been nominated: ''Kroll Show'' (Comedy Central)

The sketch category was created after seven straight years of ''Saturday Night
Live'' being the only nontalk show in the variety category (and losing). In its
new category, ''S.N.L.'' can lose to the unstoppable Ms. Schumer.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/22/arts/television/mike-hale-on-the-emmy-awards-2
015-predictions-wishes-and-what-ifs.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTOS

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

(90%); TELEVISION INDUSTRY (90%); ACTORS & ACTRESSES (89%); PUBLIC TELEVISION
(78%); TELEVISION COMEDIES (78%); TELEVISION PROGRAMMING (77%)

COMPANY: NETFLIX INC (84%); SA GUYOMARC'H ALIMENTAIRE (SAGAL) (50%)

INDUSTRY: NAICS532230 VIDEO TAPE & DISC RENTAL (84%); SIC7841 VIDEO TAPE RENTAL
(84%); SIC2013 SAUSAGES & OTHER PREPARED MEAT PRODUCTS (50%)

                              Late Edition - Final

Neil Genzlinger on the Emmy Awards 2015: Predictions, Wishes and What-Ifs

BYLINE: By NEIL GENZLINGER

SECTION: Section AR; Column 0; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 1544 words


Neil Genzlinger, one of the TV critics for The New York Times, shares his
opinions on this year's Emmy Awards, which will be hosted by Andy Samberg on
Sept. 20 on Fox.

Outstanding Drama Series

''Better Call Saul'' (AMC) ''Downton Abbey'' (PBS) ''Game of Thrones'' (HBO)
''Homeland'' (Showtime) ''House of Cards'' (Netflix) ''Mad Men'' (AMC) ''Orange
Is the New Black'' (Netflix)

Will win: ''Mad Men''Should win: ''Game of Thrones''Should have been nominated:
''The Newsroom'' (HBO)

Each nominee in this category has something to recommend, so let's give the
award to the one that has generated the most buzz. On that note, ''The
Newsroom'' had some buzz-inducing moments of its own in its final season.

Outstanding Comedy Series

''Louie'' (FX)''Modern Family'' (ABC)''Parks and Recreation'' (NBC)''Silicon
Valley'' (HBO)''Transparent'' (Amazon)''Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt''
(Netflix)''Veep'' (HBO)

Will win: ''Veep'' Should win: ''Silicon Valley''Should have been nominated:
''Brooklyn Nine-Nine''

The real-life election is dominating headlines, which works in favor of
''Veep,'' but it's ''Silicon Valley'' that actually speaks to themes that
concern us all. Fox's ''Brooklyn Nine-Nine'' got both funnier and smarter this
season.

Lead Actress, Drama

Claire Danes, ''Homeland''Viola Davis, ''How to Get Away With Murder''Taraji P.
Henson, ''Empire''Tatiana Maslany, ''Orphan Black''Elisabeth Moss, ''Mad
Men''Robin Wright, ''House of Cards''

Will win: Viola DavisShould win: Tatania MaslanyShould have been nominated: Vera
Farmiga, ''Bates Motel''

With so many fine actresses in substantive roles, Ms. Maslany, who plays a
dizzying array of characters in the identity-bending ''Orphan Black,'' deserves
to win for sheer quantity. Ms. Farmiga is a lamentable omission; her layered
performance as Norman Bates's mother is a master class.

Lead Actor, Drama

Kyle Chandler, ''Bloodline''Jeff Daniels, ''The Newsroom''Jon Hamm, ''Mad
Men''Bob Odenkirk, ''Better Call Saul''Liev Schreiber, ''Ray Donovan''Kevin
Spacey, ''House of Cards''

Will win: Jon HammShould win: Jon HammShould have been nominated: Mark Harmon,
''NCIS''

This award is overdue for Mr. Hamm. But what about Mark Harmon? Yes. Mark
Harmon. The Emmys sometimes look down on shows that are too popular and too
reliable, and ''NCIS'' has been both for years. He has kept it so of late
despite shouldering some extra burden because of the departure of the popular
character Ziva in 2013.

Lead Actress, Comedy

Edie Falco, ''Nurse Jackie''Lisa Kudrow, ''The Comeback''Julia Louis-Dreyfus,
''Veep''Amy Poehler, ''Parks and Recreation''Amy Schumer, ''Inside Amy
Schumer''Lily Tomlin, ''Grace and Frankie''

Will win: Amy SchumerShould win: Edie FalcoShould have been nominated: Constance
Wu, ''Fresh Off the Boat''

The two Amys (Schumer and Poehler) are trending, but Ms. Falco's long run
deserves to be rewarded in her series's final season. Some might question
whether Ms. Wu, the mother in ''Fresh Off the Boat,'' qualifies as a lead
actress, but in the episodes of that series that really worked in its debut
season, she got all the laughs.

Lead Actor, Comedy

Anthony Anderson, ''black-ish''Louis C.K., ''Louie''Don Cheadle, ''House of
Lies''Will Forte, ''The Last Man on Earth''Matt LeBlanc, ''Episodes''William H.
Macy, ''Shameless''Jeffrey Tambor, ''Transparent''

Will win: Jeffrey TamborShould win: William H. MacyShould have been nominated:
Thomas Middleditch, ''Silicon Valley''

This is a true turning point, both in real life and on TV, for transgender
people and for stories about them. But Mr. Macy has long done quirkily brilliant
work on ''Shameless.'' Mr. Middleditch, as the geek at the center of ''Silicon
Valley,'' makes ''socially awkward'' look way easier than it is.

Supporting Actress, Drama

Joanne Froggatt, ''Downton Abbey''Lena Headey, ''Game of Thrones''Emilia Clarke,
''Game of Thrones''Christine Baranski, ''The Good Wife''Christina Hendricks,
''Mad Men''Uzo Aduba, ''Orange Is the New Black''

Will win: Emilia ClarkeShould win: Christine BaranskiShould have been nominated:
Clara Paget, ''Black Sails''

It's time for Ms. Baranski to get some respect. And Ms. Paget deserved a
nomination just for the way she rocks that hat in Starz's underappreciated
pirate yarn.

Supporting Actor, Drama

Jonathan Banks, ''Better Call Saul''Ben Mendelsohn, ''Bloodline''Jim Carter,
''Downton Abbey''Peter Dinklage, ''Game of Thrones''Alan Cumming, ''The Good
Wife''Michael Kelly, ''House of Cards''

Will win: Peter DinklageShould win: Alan CummingShould have been nominated:
Tobias Menzies, ''Outlander''

The versatile Mr. Cumming is a worthy choice in a category that lacks a
standout. The puzzling Emmy shutout of Starz's ''Outlander'' could have been
rectified here, though the line between leading and supporting actors in that
series is a hazy one.

Supporting Actress, Comedy

Mayim Bialik, ''The Big Bang Theory''Niecy Nash, ''Getting On''Julie Bowen,
''Modern Family''Allison Janney, ''Mom''Kate McKinnon, ''Saturday Night
Live''Gaby Hoffmann, ''Transparent''Jane Krakowski, ''Unbreakable Kimmy
Schmidt''Anna Chlumsky, ''Veep''

Will win: Allison JanneyShould win: Niecy NashShould have been nominated:
Christa Miller, ''Cougar Town''

It would be nice to see the saucy but largely undiscovered ''Getting On'' get
some love. Ditto ''Cougar Town,'' which ended after six solid seasons. Ms.
Miller was a steady, deadpan anchor throughout.

Supporting Actor, Comedy

Andre Braugher, ''Brooklyn Nine-Nine''Adam Driver, ''Girls''Keegan-Michael Key,
''Key & Peele''Ty Burrell, ''Modern Family''Tituss Burgess, ''Unbreakable Kimmy
Schmidt''Tony Hale, ''Veep''

Will win: Andre BraugherShould win: Keegan-Michael KeyShould have been
nominated: Jordan Peele, ''Key & Peele''

''Key & Peele'' goes places no traditional network comedy dares go. And there's
no Key without Peele.

Best Limited Series

''American Crime'' (ABC)''American Horror Story: Freak Show'' (FX)''Olive
Kitteridge'' (HBO)''The Honorable Woman'' (Sundance)''Wolf Hall'' (PBS)

Will win: ''American Horror Story: Freak Show''

Should win: ''Olive Kitteridge''

Should have been nominated: ''The Lizzie Borden Chronicles''

There are too many weighty dramas around for the well-acted ''Olive Kitteridge''
to set itself apart, so the crowd-pleasing ''Freak Show'' has the edge. But
speaking of freaky, Christina Ricci's performance as Lizzie Borden made that
Lifetime offering a treat.

Outstanding Television Movie

''Agatha Christie's Poirot: Poirot's Last Case'' (PBS)''Bessie'' (HBO)''Grace of
Monaco'' (Lifetime)''Hello Ladies: The Movie'' (HBO)''Killing Jesus'' (National
Geographic Channel)''Nightingale'' (HBO)

Will win: ''Bessie''

Should win: ''Nightingale''

Should have been nominated: ''Beautiful & Twisted''

Queen Latifah's name recognition wins ''Bessie'' the award, though the movie
wasn't very good. Some of the other names on this list, especially ''Killing
Jesus,'' shouldn't even have been nominated. Given that this was such a weak
year for the category, why not throw in another from the ever-improving Lifetime
movie factory -- ''Beautiful & Twisted,'' a bizarre true-crime story. Rob Lowe!
Candice Bergen! What's not to like?

Animated Program

''Archer'' (FX)''Bob's Burgers'' (Fox)''Over the Garden Wall'' (Cartoon
Network)''The Simpsons'' (Fox)''South Park'' (Comedy Central)

Will win: ''The Simpsons''

Should win: ''South Park''

Should have been nominated: ''Rick and Morty'' (Adult Swim)

Throw a dart at your TV these days, and you're bound to hit a witty and
outlandish animated show. This award could go to any of them. ''South Park''
passed 250 episodes this season and is still pushing boundaries. Amazing.

Outstanding Reality Competition Show

''The Amazing Race'' (CBS)''Dancing With the Stars'' (ABC)''Project Runway''
(Lifetime)''So You Think You Can Dance'' (Fox)''Top Chef'' (Bravo)''The Voice''
(NBC)

Will win: ''The Voice''Should win: ''The Voice''Should have been nominated:
''The Quest''

A lot of same-old, same-old here. ''The Quest,'' a fantasy-themed competition
show on ABC, didn't draw many viewers, but it was more interesting than the rest
of this crop.

Outstanding Variety Series

''The Colbert Report'' (Comedy Central)''The Daily Show With Jon Stewart''
(Comedy Central)''Jimmy Kimmel Live'' (ABC)''Last Week Tonight With John
Oliver'' (HBO)''Late Show With David Letterman'' (CBS)''The Tonight Show
Starring Jimmy Fallon'' (NBC)

Will win: ''The Colbert Report''Should win: ''Last Week Tonight With John
Oliver''Should have been nominated: ''Conan'' (TBS)

So many finales; who gets the thank-you award? Mr. Colbert, because voters are
grateful that he's returning rather than retiring. But John Oliver's ''Last Week
Tonight'' is now setting the standard in this genre. The rest seem stodgy by
comparison.

Outstanding Variety Sketch Series

''Drunk History'' (Comedy Central)''Inside Amy Schumer'' (Comedy Central)''Key &
Peele'' (Comedy Central)''Portlandia'' (IFC)''Saturday Night Live'' (NBC)

Will win: ''Inside Amy Schumer''Should win: ''Key & Peele''Should have been
nominated: ''Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee'' (Crackle)

Does Jerry Seinfeld's cars-and-comics show fit into this category? Who knows.
But it's a delight.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/22/arts/television/neil-genzlinger-on-the-emmy-aw
ards-2015-predictions-wishes-and-what-ifs.html

(89%); PUBLIC TELEVISION (78%); TELEVISION PROGRAMMING (77%); FAMILY (71%);
HOTELS & MOTELS (50%)

Paid Notice: Deaths WOLLMAN, ANNE CAROLYN

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 359 words


WOLLMAN--Anne Carolyn, died at the age of 82 on June 5, 2015. She was a
prominent and discriminating collector of art works including ceramics, prints,
and paintings; and was known for her impeccable taste in the clothing and
jewelry she wore. The Vermont home that she and her husband designed was filled
with works of art and antiques. Some of the ceramics and prints constituted the
material for a show called Cross Currents in 20th Century Art, at the Currier
Museum in Manchester, New Hampshire, during the summer of 2010. As an
enthusiastic supporter of the arts and the artists who created them, she curated
a number of ceramic shows on compelling intellectual and artistic themes, such
as Vanitas and After Palissy.

She served as a trustee of many organizations, including The Clay Studio of
Philadelphia; Watershed Center for the Ceramic Arts, Newcastle, Maine; and The
Vermont Arts Council. She is remembered by those who knew her for her
comprehensive knowledge of the field of art, her unerring eye, and the gently
mischievous teasing which was reserved for certain special friends. She was a
graduate of Radcliffe College in 1954, and of the Harvard-Radcliffe Graduate
Program in Business Administration in 1955. Her three daughters also graduated
from Harvard College and are pursuing careers: Julie as President of Edinboro
University of Pennsylvania; Emily as a Senior Director of Med Assets, a hospital
management and consulting firm; and Diana in tax law as a partner in Cleary
Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton. The older of her two grandchildren, Sara, is starting
a career in art therapy; and the younger, Rosa, is currently attending Harvard
College. Anne Carolyn Wollman is survived by her husband of 58 years, Harry, who
was a former Medical School Dean, and is now a partner in Alexander, Wollman and
Stark, where he serves as an advisor to executives and developer of talent for
academic medical centers. Memorial services will be held in Woodstock, VT on
September 20, and in Philadelphia on October 17. Donations may be sent to the
Anne and Harry Wollman Scholarship Fund at Edinboro University, 210 Meadville
St., Edinboro, PA, 16444. 1/3

URL:

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Paid Death Notice

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Paid Notice: Deaths MILLER, DOUGLAS HOWARD

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 157 words


MILLER--Douglas Howard. After a long illness, Douglas Howard Miller passed away
on July 21, 2015 at his home in Naples, Florida -- just days after he celebrated
his one hundredth birthday. Mr Miller is survived by his wife of eighteen years,
Grace Lurton Miller of New York and Connecticut. He also leaves daughters Leslie
Taylor and Sara Miller of Massachusetts and five grandchildren of his 57-year
marriage to the late Barbara Miller. Mr. Miller's long career was highlighted by
many years as comptroller of the General Foods Corporation here and prospector
of business development abroad. Mr. Miller took special pride in his
career-capping ten years in New Jersey where he introduced public financing and
business development to the still-growing campus of Montclair State University.
The family expects to have a private memorial service on Tuesday, July 28th at
the First Congregational Church in former hometown Madison, Connecticut. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths LEONE, RICHARD C

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 393 words


LEONE--Richard C. Former president of the Century Foundation and a past chairman
of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, died on Thursday, July 16. He
was 75 years old. He was being treated for Parkinson's disease and was recently
diagnosed with prostate cancer. Born in Webster, New York in 1940, Dick Leone
spent the bulk of his career in public service.

A graduate of the University of Rochester, he earned a Masters degree and a PhD
at Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. A
pragmatic progressive whose views were forged during the Kennedy era, Leone
worked on many local and national campaigns. One of his proudest moments was
working as an advance man on Robert Kennedy's presidential campaign in Oregon.
He also worked on presidential campaigns for George McGovern, Walter Mondale,
Michael Dukakis and Bill Bradley. In the '60s, he was executive director of the
White House Task Force on The Cities. In addition, Leone managed Brendan Byrne's
two successful campaigns for Governor of New Jersey, in 1973 and 1977. From 1974
to 1977, Leone was state treasurer of New Jersey. In 2005, he served as chairman
of Governor Jon Corzine's transition committee. Leone served as a commissioner
of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, and was chairman of the Port
Authority from 1990 to 1994. From 1989 to 2011, he was president of the Century
Foundation (formerly Twentieth Century Fund), a public policy think tank. Leone
steered the foundation to concentrate on such issues as inequality and civil
liberties and he fought against attempts at privatizing Social Security. Leone's
private sector jobs included working as President of the New York Mercantile
Exchange and a managing director at Dillon Read & Co. He has long been a
director/trustee of multiple funds at Dreyfus Corp. and serves on the board of
the Center for American Progress. Burial is private, but a memorial service will
take place in Princeton, New Jersey in September. He is survived by his wife,
Meg Cox Leone; his children Kate Leone and Max Leone, and his granddaughter Lucy
Kirschner, as well as his sister Sandra Leone Thomas Brooks and first wife,
Anita Leone. As well as many nieces, nephews and cousins. Those wishing to honor
his memory can consider donations to New Jersey Policy Perspective or the
Michael J. Fox Foundation. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths HARRIS, ELLEN

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 343 words


HARRIS--Ellen. Passed away on July 7 after a long battle with pancreatic cancer.
A magnetic, compelling woman, Ellen attracted a broad and deep range of smart
and wise people throughout her life.

She brought people together. Her extraordinary immediate and extended family,
remarkably strong circles of friends from different walks of life, political
associates from her work for Senator Jacob Javits in Washington D.C. in the
'70s, and legal colleagues in New Jersey and New York energized her life. To all
of them she was an anchor, ally, advisor, and unwavering friend. Practicing
lawyer for 37 years, Ellen was a Counsel of Securities Law at Sidley Austin LLP
in Manhattan, where she specialized in funds and investments. With a 1969 B.A.
from University of Rochester, 1970 M.A. in history from Stanford University, and
a 1977 J.D. from New York University School of Law, she recognized the
importance of education and served on the Board of Trustees at The Pingry School
in Martinsville, NJ, where her two loving sons, Michael and David, graduated. An
exemplary mother, she showed unwavering devotion to them and pride in their
accomplishments. In addition to her loving family, she became an honorary mother
and aunt to innumerable others, with kindness, class, and intelligent guidance.
Ellen's parents, Mimi West (driving force behind the Los Angeles Free Clinic for
three decades, and founder of Friends of the Los Angeles Free Clinic) and Bernie
West (Emmy-winning writer of All in the Family, and producer of Three's Company)
instilled in Ellen and in her sister, Isabel, both a love of culture and fine
arts and the importance of giving back to society. She was a patron of The
Shakespeare Theatre of New Jersey and on the Board of the Rioult Dance New York,
and she hosted fundraising events to champion the causes and cultural
celebrations in which she believed. Donations in her name can be made to some of
her favorite arts charities Rioult Dance, New York City Ballet, or the
Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey. She will be deeply missed. 1/3

Paid Notice: Deaths BUNZEL, PETER D

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Classified; Pg. 22

BUNZEL--Peter D. His family mourns the passing of journalist Peter D. Bunzel,
aged 88, on July 20, 2015 in Los Angeles, CA. Peter began his professional
career at the (Martha's) Vineyard Gazette, and was later a staff writer at the
New Yorker, Entertainment Editor at Life Magazine, Co-Founder, Editor and
Publisher of Seattle Magazine (1963 to 1970), Editor of West Magazine and of the
Opinion section of the Los Angeles Times (1971 to 1978), and a television critic
at the Los Angeles Herald-Examiner where in 1986 he won a major victory for free
speech in the California Supreme Court, 42 Cal.

3d 254. Born in 1927 in New York, NY to Harriet Harvey and Ernest Everett
Bunzel, Peter attended Allen-Stevenson, the Kent School and Princeton University
where he was Editor and Chairman of the Daily Princetonian. In 1952, he married
Jane Cole (deceased) and had four children: Cole Bunzel (deceased), Robert H.
Bunzel of Oakland, CA, Jeffrey H. Bunzel of New York, NY and John D. Bunzel of
Los Angeles, CA. In 1982, Peter married Suzanne Belcher Platt in Los Angeles,
CA. Peter was devoted to books, movies, theatre, martinis, politics, freighter
trips and family. He is survived by his wife Suzanne, his brother John H. Bunzel
of Belmont, CA, his three sons, eight grandchildren and two great-grandsons. A
celebration of his life for family and friends will be held in September in Los
Angeles. 1/3
