Brando's Gone, Yet Not Silenced

BYLINE: By NEIL GENZLINGER

SECTION: Section AR; Column 0; Arts and Leisure Desk; FILM; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 153 words


Marlon Brando has been dead 11 years, but he lives eerily on in ''Listen to Me
Marlon,'' which begins a two-week run on July 29 at Film Forum. The movie
creates a fitful biography of Brando using hundreds of hours of audio recordings
he made and a weird holographic head of the actor. With Brando's somewhat trippy
observations as a guide, it looks at career highlights as well as the personal
calamities that seemed to follow the man, like the suicide of his daughter
Cheyenne.

''By skipping across time and steering clear of the usual biographical tidiness
(birth, life, death), the director Stevan Riley both avoids the usual great-man
traps and makes Mr. Brando come searchingly alive,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The
New York Times when the film played at New Directors/New Films in March.

''Listen to Me Marlon'' is a teaser for a 10-movie tribute to Brando that Film
Forum has scheduled for Aug. 7-11 (filmforum.org).

U.S. Gets Favorable Draw in Qualifying Tournament for World Cup in Russia

BYLINE: By SAM BORDEN

SECTION: Section SP; Column 0; Sports Desk; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 716 words


The first step toward the 2018 World Cup in Russia appears to be a relatively
simple one for the United States men's national team.

The Americans received a favorable grouping on Saturday, as FIFA held its draw
for the World Cup qualifying tournament during an elaborate ceremony in St.
Petersburg, Russia. The United States will face Trinidad and Tobago and the
winners of matches between St. Vincent and the Grenadines and Aruba, and Antigua
and Barbuda and Guatemala.

If the United States finishes as one of the top two teams after its group
concludes home-and-away round-robin play, it will advance to the final round of
qualifying, known as the hexagonal, which pits six teams against one another in
another home-and-away round robin. Three guaranteed spots in the World Cup are
available, with the fourth-place team entering a playoff with a team from Asia.

Group B appears to be the most difficult of the Concacaf groups drawn on
Saturday, as Panama and Costa Rica could end up being joined by Jamaica and
Haiti. Mexico and Honduras were the top two teams in Group A.

Technically, the United States is entering the qualifying tournament at the
fourth round, as Concacaf -- the regional governing body overseeing soccer in
the North and Central America and the Caribbean -- has 35 members, and 17 were
previously eliminated in the opening rounds. Nations like Montserrat and the
Bahamas have already seen their hopes of making the World Cup end before the
United States's path has even begun.

In addition to the drawing of the teams -- as well as a variety of dance
routines and other entertainment -- Saturday's event served as a significant
milestone for organizers of the World Cup in Russia.

As controversy over alleged corruption has enveloped FIFA in recent months,
questions about the fate of the Russia World Cup and the 2022 event, in Qatar,
have persisted. The awarding of hosting rights for those two tournaments has
been scrutinized for potential improprieties. While Russian organizers have
stated repeatedly they did nothing untoward in trying to win the bid, there has
been speculation that the 2018 or 2022 tournament could be moved if it is proved
that organizers acted improperly.

With the qualifying draw being held on Saturday, however, it seems all but
certain that Russia's tournament will proceed as planned, if only because
Russia's national team, as hosts, was not drawn into the qualifying tournament
for Europe.

Re-inserting a team once qualifying has begun -- if, say, the tournament were
shifted to another country -- would seem all but impossible.

Along those lines, FIFA's powerful executive committee used the spectacle of the
draw as an opportunity to reiterate its support for Russia as hosts.

Sepp Blatter, the departing president of FIFA, told Vladimir V. Putin, the
president of Russia, that soccer's governing body was fully committed to staging
the 2018 event in 11 cities across the world's largest country.

''I would like to inform you that the executive committee has recently adopted a
new resolution in which FIFA assures the Russian Federation of its full support
in carrying out the World Cup in Russia in 2018,'' Mr. Blatter said.

Mr. Blatter announced in June that he would step down as president, just days
after being elected to a fifth four-year term. Mr. Blatter has since said that
the main reason he made this decision is because of the crisis that has
surrounded FIFA amidst corruption investigations by authorities from the United
States and Switzerland. Mr. Blatter has not been charged, but as FIFA's leader,
he is under scrutiny.

It was not surprising that Mr. Blatter, who has limited his travel outside
Switzerland since the investigations were made public, chose to take part in the
event in Russia. Mr. Putin has been a supporter of Mr. Blatter and criticized
the United States's investigation into FIFA as interfering in issues outside its
purview.

On Saturday, Mr. Putin promised that Russia would deliver ''a grandiose
international sporting festival,'' while thanking Mr. Blatter and FIFA for its
support during a difficult time.

''We see what is happening around soccer,'' Mr. Putin said, ''but I know how you
regard this and we are grateful that you are concentrating your attention
primarily on sport.''

When Debate Became Bloodsport

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM

SECTION: Section AR; Column 0; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 1236 words


Before partisan panels, split-screen shoutfests and brash personalities became
ubiquitous on cable news, there were two men who despised each other sitting
side by side on a drab soundstage, debating politics in prime time during the
presidential nominating conventions of 1968. There were Gore Vidal and William
F. Buckley Jr.

Literary aristocrats and ideological foes, Vidal and Buckley attracted millions
of viewers to what, at the time, was a highly irregular experiment: the
spectacle of two brilliant minds slugging it out -- once, almost literally -- on
live television. It was witty, erudite and ultimately vicious, an early
intrusion of full-contact punditry into the staid pastures of the evening news.

What transpired would alter both men's lives -- and, as a new documentary
argues, help change the course of how the American political media reports the
news. ''Best of Enemies,'' which opens July 31, makes the case that their
on-screen feuding opened the floodgates for today's opinionated, conflict-driven
coverage.

The film might have been a sober lesson in the erosion of our civic discourse,
timed to the start of yet another 24/7 presidential campaign. But its directors,
Morgan Neville and Robert Gordon, present their ideas with a wide scope,
exploring the rivalry between their subjects and evoking an era when public
intellectuals like Vidal appeared on ''Playboy After Dark'' and magazine editors
like Buckley, the founder of National Review, ran for mayor of New York. (He
lost.)

''They don't make people like Gore Vidal and William F. Buckley anymore,'' Mr.
Neville said in a recent interview. ''Their lives are the kind of American lives
that people don't have anymore. To me, just on a theatrical level, it seemed
operatic: this kind of grand battle.''

The film's trump card is the debates themselves -- first during the Republicans'
convention in Miami, then three weeks later during the Democrats' in Chicago --
resurrected in rarely seen footage that, 47 years on, remains almost giddily
entertaining: ''Crossfire'' with a script by Noël Coward.

Vidal tells Buckley that he was an inspiration for Myra Breckinridge, Vidal's
transgender literary creation: ''passionate and irrelevant.'' Buckley mocks
Vidal's failed screenplays and produces a note from Robert F. Kennedy, killed
weeks earlier, suggesting that Vidal be deported to Vietnam. (Vidal, examining
the letter, notes that the handwriting is slanted upward: ''sign of a
manic-depressive,'' he says coolly.)

Anchors like Howard K. Smith and Walter Cronkite had occasionally offered
commentaries on the news, ''but that was very civil,'' Mr. Neville said. ''What
they brought,'' he added, referring to Vidal and Buckley, ''was a whole other
level of incivility that television hadn't really seen.''

Mr. Neville, who won the feature documentary Oscar for ''20 Feet From Stardom,''
and Mr. Gordon, a longtime collaborator, first watched the debates in 2010, on a
bootleg copy from a friend. ''I immediately was taken by how contemporary it
was,'' Mr. Gordon said, noting that between zingers, Buckley and Vidal were
debating foreign wars, racial justice and states' rights.

But the directors, both former journalists, also discovered that the debates'
legacy became more about ire than ideas.

Buckley showcased provocative debate on ''Firing Line,'' his program which had
its debut in 1966; Vidal was a mischievous guest on talk shows. But the film
presents network news in 1968 as a gray affair. When ABC hired Buckley and Vidal
to hold daily debates during its convention coverage -- essentially a ratings
stunt by a network ranked last in the ratings -- it was breaking from the
gavel-to-gavel norm.

And then some. On a night of riots at the Democratic convention in Chicago,
Buckley and Vidal had their own climactic on-air clash. Vidal called Buckley a
''crypto-Nazi,'' prompting a reaction that still stuns.

''Now listen, you queer,'' Buckley replied, ''stop calling me a crypto-Nazi or
I'll sock you in the goddamn face and you'll stay plastered.'' He was nearly out
of his chair, inches from Vidal, his face, as Christopher Hitchens recalls in
the film, ''a rictus of loathing.''

Such slurs are rarely heard on television today; at the time, they were deeply
profane, and the exchange was cut from the West Coast broadcast, according to
Mr. Gordon. Vidal saw it as a triumph; Buckley almost never spoke of it again.

''Best of Enemies'' documents the aftermath: News producers, intrigued by ABC's
ratings increase, began pitting liberals against conservatives. A montage
features an old ''Point/Counterpoint'' segment from ''60 Minutes''; Jon Stewart
berating the hosts of CNN's ''Crossfire''; and shouty clips from Fox News.

The film, which debuted this year at Sundance, has resonated: The screenwriter
Aaron Sorkin recently signed on to write a feature-length dramatic adaptation.
''I'd never heard about the Vidal/Buckley debates before seeing the
documentary,'' Mr. Sorkin said by email, comparing the climactic debate to ''a
classic courtroom scene.''

Research for the documentary took years, with the directors plumbing archives
for gems like Vidal's handwritten debate notes. (Many of his supposed ad-libs
were, in fact, rehearsed.) The directors interviewed Vidal in 2010, two years
before his death, at his Hollywood home, where he initially accused them of
being Buckley partisans. ''It was like a scene from 'Sunset Boulevard,' '' Mr.
Neville recalled.

That interview does not appear in the film; Buckley died in 2008, and the
directors felt allowing only Vidal to speak would unbalance the film. Instead,
they draw on journalists, media critics and relatives, including Buckley's
brother Reid. Buckley's son, Christopher, declined to speak. ''I think it was
honoring his father's intentions to not ever speak of the V-word again,'' Mr.
Neville said.

Mr. Neville, who briefly worked as a fact-checker for Vidal after college (''One
of the most thankless jobs I've ever had''), said that audiences frequently tell
him how relevant the film seems to today's media culture. Mr. Gordon regards
that as a hopeful sign. ''People are hungry for the public intellectual,'' Mr.
Gordon said. Buckley and Vidal ''had 15 minutes a night, uninterrupted. Imagine
that today. Imagine having two witty, literate heavy thinkers having a go at
each other for 15 minutes without someone in the headset saying, 'Quick, talk
about Monica Lewinsky's underwear.' ''

Mr. Neville agreed. ''Now, you watch cable news, and you know what everybody's
going to say before they open their mouth,'' he said. Buckley and Vidal ''were
independent thinkers, and independent thinkers aren't given a lot of time on
television today.''

Few current news programs can match the lexical fireworks of the Buckley-Vidal
debates, and it is true that the words ''Latinate'' and ''hobgoblinization'' are
unlikely to be heard on CNN anytime soon.

But ''Best of Enemies'' also proves something else: that even during a more
genteel era in television news, the most pedigreed and respected intellects
could descend into name-calling and, for a moment, the threat of physical
violence.

Mr. Sorkin, who lamented the state of television news in his HBO series, ''The
Newsroom,'' was asked what today's news media might learn from these debates
nearly half a century old.

''I think they've learned it,'' Mr. Sorkin replied. ''Incivility rates.''




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/26/movies/buckley-vs-vidal-when-debate-became-blo
odsport.html

one of their 1968 debates

Convention. ''Best of Enemies'' recalls Vidal's debates with William F. Buckley
Jr. during both conventions. (PHOTOGRAPH BY MAGNOLIA PICTURES) (A16)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: POLITICS (90%); TELEVISION PROGRAMMING (90%); MEN (78%); CONFERENCES &
CONVENTIONS (78%); PRIMETIME TELEVISION (78%); DRAMA LITERATURE (77%); US
DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL CONVENTIONS (77%); POLITICAL PARTY CONVENTIONS (77%); US
REPUBLICAN PARTY (73%); MOVIE RELEASE DATES (73%); US DEMOCRATIC PARTY (73%);
DOCUMENTARY FILMS (73%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (72%); INTERVIEWS (70%); MAYORS
(66%); DEPORTATION (50%)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%)

                               The New York Times

                              July 26, 2015 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

Editors' Choice | Recent Books of Particular Interest

SECTION: Section BR; Column 0; Book Review Desk; Pg. 22

LENGTH: 315 words


THE WEATHER EXPERIMENT: The Pioneers Who Sought to See the Future, by Peter
Moore. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) Unlike many British-centric
meteorological histories, Moore's evocative account pays homage to American
contributions.

BIG SCIENCE: Ernest Lawrence and the Invention That Launched the
Military-Industrial Complex, by Michael Hiltzik. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) The
origins of the trend toward today's gargantuan projects.

THE PINCH: A History, by Steve Stern. (Graywolf, $26.) There's nothing Stern
can't imagine in this manically busy fabulist novel, a long Yiddish folk tale
transplanted to the American South.

THE GODDESS POSE: The Audacious Life of Indra Devi, the Woman Who Helped Bring
Yoga to the West, by Michelle Goldberg. (Knopf, $26.95.) This elegant biography
shows the influential yogini in the thick of many crucial 20th-century events.

BARBARIAN DAYS: A Surfing Life, by William Finnegan. (Penguin Press, $27.95.)
Generous yet unsparing portraits of competitive surf friend- ships are among the
joys of Finnegan's memoir.

OUR MAN IN CHARLESTON: Britain's Secret Agent in the Civil War South, by
Christopher Dickey. (Crown, $27.) How a diplomat in South Carolina helped keep
his country out of the war.

THE WOLF BORDER, by Sarah Hall. (Harper, $25.99.) Hall's satisfying, big-themed
novel tracks a self-determined woman involved with the reintroduction of the
gray wolf into England.

LET ME EXPLAIN YOU, by Annie Liontas. (Scribner, $26.) A patriarch's ambiguous
countdown to death stakes out this novel's risky comic territory.

RISE, by Karen Campbell. (Bloomsbury, $28.) In Campbell's vivid novel, a Glasgow
prostitute flees her pimp and finds work as a nanny.

Like to be first? Get The New York Times Book Review before it appears online
every Friday.                           Sign up for the email newsletter here.

                               The New York Times

                              July 26, 2015 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

Looking Away From Abortion

BYLINE: By ROSS DOUTHAT

SECTION: Section SR; Column 0; Sunday Review Desk; OP-ED COLUMNIST; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 864 words


IN an essay in his 1976 collection, ''Mortal Lessons,'' the physician Richard
Selzer describes a strange suburban scene. People go outside in the morning in
his neighborhood, after the garbage trucks have passed, and find ''a foreignness
upon the pavement,'' a softness underfoot.

Looking down, Selzer first thinks he sees oversize baby birds, then rubber baby
dolls, until the realization comes that the street is littered with the tiny,
naked, all-too-human bodies of aborted fetuses.

Later, the local hospital director speaks to Selzer, trying to impose order on
the grisly scene. It was an accident, of course: The tiny corpses were
accidentally ''mixed up with the other debris'' instead of being incinerated or
interred. ''It is not an everyday occurrence. Once in a lifetime, he says.''

And Selzer tries to nod along: ''Now you see. It is orderly. It is sensible. The
world is not mad. This is still a civilized society...

''But just this once, you know it isn't. You saw, and you know.''

Resolute abortion rights supporters would dismiss that claim of knowledge. Death
and viscera are never pretty, they would say, but something can be disgusting
without being barbaric. Just because it's awful to discover fetuses underfoot
doesn't mean the unborn have a right to life.

And it's precisely this argument that's been marshaled lately in response to a
new reminder of the fleshly realities of abortion: The conversations, videotaped
covertly by pro-life activists posing as fetal organ buyers, in which officials
from Planned Parenthood cheerfully discuss the procedures for extracting those
organs intact during an abortion and the prices they command.

It may be disturbing to hear those procedures described: ''... we've been very
good at getting heart, lung, liver, because we know that, so I'm not gonna crush
that part, I'm gonna basically crush below, I'm gonna crush above, and I'm gonna
see if I can get it all intact.''


It may be unseemly to hear a Planned Parenthood official haggle over pricing for
those organs: ''Let me just figure out what others are getting, and if this is
in the ballpark, then it's fine, if it's still low, then we can bump it up. I
want a Lamborghini.''


But in the end, Planned Parenthood's defenders insist, listening to an
abortionist discuss manipulating the ''calvarium'' (that is, the dying fetus's
skull) so that it emerges research-ready from the womb is fundamentally no
different than listening to a doctor discuss heart surgery or organ transplants.
It's unsettling, yes, but just because it's gross doesn't prove it's wrong.

Which is true, but in this case not really true enough. Because real knowledge
isn't purely theoretical; it's the fruit of experience, recognition,
imagination, life itself.

And the problem these videos create for Planned Parenthood isn't just a
generalized queasiness at surgery and blood.

It's a very specific disgust, informed by reason and experience -- the reasoning
that notes that it's precisely a fetus's humanity that makes its organs
valuable, and the experience of recognizing one's own children, on the
ultrasound monitor and after, as something more than just ''products of
conception'' or tissue for the knife.

That's why Planned Parenthood's apologists have fallen back on complaints about
''deceptive editing'' (though full videos were released in both cases), or else
simply asked people to look away. And it's why many of my colleagues in the
press seem uncomfortable reporting on the actual content of the videos.

Because dwelling on that content gets you uncomfortably close to Selzer's
tipping point -- that moment when you start pondering the possibility that an
institution at the heart of respectable liberal society is dedicated to a
practice that deserves to be called barbarism.

That's a hard thing to accept. It's part of why so many people hover in the
conflicted borderlands of the pro-choice side. They don't like abortion, they
think its critics have a point ... but to actively join our side would require
passing too comprehensive a judgment on their coalition, their country, their
friends, their very selves.

This reluctance is a human universal. It's why white Southerners long preferred
Lost Cause mythology to slaveholding realities. It's why patriotic Americans
rarely want to dwell too long on My Lai or Manzanar or Nagasaki. It's why, like
many conservatives, I was loath to engage with the reality of torture in
Bush-era interrogation programs.

But the reluctance to look closely doesn't change the truth of what there is to
see. Those were dead human beings on Richard Selzer's street 40 years ago, and
these are dead human beings being discussed on video today: Human beings that
the nice, idealistic medical personnel at Planned Parenthood have spent their
careers crushing, evacuating, and carving up for parts.

The pro-life sting was sweeping; there are reportedly 10 videos to go. You can
turn away. But there will be plenty of chances to look, to see, to know.

I invite you to follow me on Twitter at twitter.com/DouthatNYT.

Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and Twitter, and sign up
for the Opinion Today newsletter.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/26/opinion/sunday/ross-douthat-looking-away-from-
abortion.html

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: ABORTION (91%); REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH CLINICS (89%); HOSPITALS (73%);
SURGERY & TRANSPLANTATION (73%); TRANSPLANT SURGERY (68%)

LOAD-DATE: July 26, 2015


                   Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

                               The New York Times

                              July 26, 2015 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

Continental Cooking and Water Views

BYLINE: By M. H. REED

SECTION: Section WE; Column 0; Metropolitan Desk; DINING | MAHOPAC; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 819 words


Beautiful Lake Mahopac is still there but the Terrace Club along its shore is no
more.

In its place is Il Laghetto, with a new menu that seems eager to revive the
1970s and that embraces the kind of cooking once called ''continental.'' It's
often met with a sneer these days, but whatever the label, well-crafted,
clear-flavored dishes are always in fashion and always welcome. In operation
since October 2014, Il Laghetto's kitchen is still in flux. Preparations are
uneven and inconsistent: what is unacceptable on one visit might be the
must-have dish on another.

However, at this moment, the draw here is the lake, and the pleasure crafts and
water skiers are lovely to watch while waiting for food from a slow kitchen. But
a bowl of popcorn comes to every table, although we preferred nibbling on slices
of good bread dipped in a mix of olives and oil.

Asian tempura calamari was the appetizer not to be missed. The tempura batter
was gossamer, and the rings of calamari so crisp, fresh and piping hot from the
fryer that we wanted to order another plateful. Mayonnaise and marinara dipping
sauces were mild but pleasant. Less interesting but almost as successful were a
pair of rollatini, the wafers of eggplant young and the tomato sauce sheer and
light.

But other appetizers had little to recommend them, including bland crab cakes
that were long on filling but short on crab meat; Prince Edward Island mussels
in a white wine sauce that needed the zing of garlic; and an unappetizingly dark
disaster of old flabby mushroom caps stuffed with escargots set in a pool of
what might have been beet juice.

Refreshing and green, Caesar salad delivered the usual mix of chopped romaine,
croutons, grana padano and a few white anchovies. But the Caprese salad came
built on anemic tomatoes, roasted red peppers and slices of tough, dry
mozzarella.

The kitchen is said to make its own pasta, and judging from the lobster ravioli,
pasta dishes might be worth a try. A tad thick, the pasta, enclosing a somewhat
scant lobster filling, was nonetheless gorgeously supple. But the presentation
lacked finesse, as the ravioli came under a flood of marinara sauce. A heap of
good mussels mingled with black fettuccine, but careless timing had the pasta
cooked to mush.

Similar inconsistencies appeared among the entrees that could be as good as four
large, succulent sea scallops paired with a mound of fluffy polenta or a New
York strip steak almost three inches thick. Though a bit chewy, it had fine
beefy flavor. I took most of it home, and it made excellent sandwiches for the
next few days.

Among the disappointments was an odd version of shrimp scampi, which set five
sizable, bland shrimp on a mound of unseasoned, overcooked rice; and the Amish
chicken was so tough and dry that it resisted the knife.

Vegetable garnishes -- a few stalks of asparagus or green beans -- were meager,
especially in light of farmers' markets bursting this year with bumper crops.

Desserts are made in-house and they are impressive. Under a thick, dense topping
of white chocolate cream, layers of strawberry shortcake came laced with
fragrant strawberry syrup, but too few fresh strawberries. A genuine hit,
however, was the cappuccino cheesecake. From the coffee-infused cake to the Art
Deco extravaganza of mocha buttercream paving the top, the cake was a rich treat
-- and a happy way to end an evening. Even better was stepping onto the dock and
taking a last look at glistening Lake Mahopac, just beginning to redden under
the afterglow of sunset.

il Laghetto

825 South Lake Street, Mahopac845-621-5200illaghettorestaurant.com

Fair

THE SPACE: Splendid views of water sports and Lake Mahopac from an outdoor deck
with booths and tables. Inside, a raised bar overlooks the dining room with a
sky blue ceiling, crystal chandeliers, and a partial view of the lake.
Wheelchair accessible.

THE CROWD: Everyone in neat casual dress. The wait staff seems inexperienced,
but is alert and very willing to please from a slow kitchen. Live music on
Sundays. DJ on Thursday nights from 8 to 11 in a candlelit lounge.

THE BAR: Full bar with a modest selection of wines. Bottles from $25 to $100;
glass, $7 to $10. Cocktails, $9 to $12. Beer, $6.50.

THE BILL: Lunch and brunch entrees, $13 to $19. Dinner entrees, $19 to $33, more
for some specials. Some prices online might be a tad lower than those at the
restaurant.

WHAT WE LIKED: Asian tempura calamari, eggplant rollatini, lobster ravioli,
seared sea scallops, cappuccino cheesecake.

IF YOU GO: Lunch: Mondays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Dinner: Mondays
through Thursdays, 3 to 10 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 3 to 11 p.m.; Sundays, 3
to 9 p.m. Brunch: Sundays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Reservations are not taken for
seating on the deck. Tight parking lot adjoins the restaurant. Valet parking on
weekends.

RATINGS: Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair, Poor.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/26/nyregion/restaurant-review-dining-at-il-laghet
to-with-a-view-of-the-sunset.html

left, the seared sea scallops with polenta, green beans and red wine syrup.
Left, cappuccino cheesecake. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY LISA WILTSE FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Farm-to-Table With a Mission

BYLINE: By MARISSA ROTHKOPF BATES

SECTION: Section NJ; Column 0; Metropolitan Desk; DINING | WARWICK, N.Y.; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 975 words


The Grange in Warwick, N.Y., which is just over the New Jersey border, is truly
a farm-to-table restaurant.

It is not just because it uses produce from farms in the magically fertile Black
Dirt region of southern New York State, or because Jim Haurey, the owner and
head ''cook'' (he dislikes the title ''chef'' when describing himself) spends
Tuesdays and Wednesdays working on an organic farm (run by his girlfriend,
Dominique Herman), or even because 80 percent of the restaurant's ingredients
are sourced locally. It is because Mr. Haurey seems to be on a mission that goes
way beyond owning a profitable business.

''This is more than a restaurant to me,'' he said in an interview after my
visits. ''It's about community. To be able to create jobs, support local farmers
and get people to eat real food.''

The Grange is in a 112-year-old former post office, located in the hamlet of New
Milford, near Warwick's antique-shop-filled town center. A large chalkboard with
the day's specials greets guests as they walk into the cozy, low-key space. A
printed menu lists a substantial cheeseburger, as well as fish and chips
approved by my British husband.

The menu also offers a plate of large and lusty onion rings, fried in beer
batter, which are worthy of their own paragraph. In a region famous for onion
farms (Polish settlers in the region apparently found its soil to be similar to
that of their homeland, and commenced with the onion farming, along with the
Germans and the Dutch), there could be no better homage to the previous tillers
of the peat-rich soil than these.

All vegetables get treated with reverence here, even the most ordinary. On both
my visits, as we waited for our appetizers, the kitchen sent a little vegetable
gift along with homemade rolls and a dish of garlicky olive oil. One night,
there was a plate of long French radishes spread with butter and touched with
salt. Even turnips, the punch line of vegetables, enjoyed a Cinderella moment
one evening, when a plate of raw baby turnip slices appeared topped with the
first of the season's basil pesto.

On our first visit, our table of four shared a smooth chicken liver pâté and a
delicate salad of greens, farmers' cheese and fresh figs, and then squabbled
over a dish piled high with tempura garlic scapes. Another appetizer, a miso and
egg drop soup -- enriched with egg, vegetables and fried won ton skins -- was
hearty and unforgettable. I swear this soup reached out and hugged me.

Yet, on another visit, my husband patiently chewed his way through the sockeye
salmon sashimi salad I had ordered. It was a well-meaning plate, but the fish,
however fresh, was lost in a sea of salad and desperate for something salty to
bring out its rich flavor. Fumbles such as these were rare and quickly
forgotten. Indeed, after I fobbed the salad onto my husband, I hunched
protectively over a bowl of homemade capellini, served with dandelion greens in
a Parmigiano-Reggiano enriched broth. I may actually have growled at the waiter
who tried to take it from me before I could sop up the peppery broth with bread.

On another night, one of my guests tucked into a hanger steak that had spent its
earlier existence pastured in the Hudson Valley. Served atop a pile of mashed
potatoes, the steak was garnished with disks of cheery yellow summer squash and
blue cheese from a nearby dairy farm. The star of the evening, however, was a
locally sourced pork chop, where radishes and turnips once again made an
appearance, this time roasted and served atop a pile of garlicky basmati rice.

Desserts were homey with quiet, sophisticated touches. A banana split featured
brûléed bananas, the shards of which mixed with the homemade vanilla ice cream
to produce something magical. A dark chocolate pot de crème, drizzled with
local-made cherry cordial, was pudding for grown-ups.

It is my duty as a critic to point out that the skin on my otherwise delicious
seared duck breast could have been crispier; that a dish of perch was
strong-armed into bland submission by its accompanying bulgur (also: who really
goes out to eat bulgur?); and that I should not have to ask for water three
times. But in the end we all left content, happy to be out among the fireflies
on a summer evening, with bellies full, after an impressive meal.

''It's just honest-to-goodness food. It's what food is supposed to be,'' Mr.
Haurey said of his cooking style.

Like the lowly turnip, it is what you make of it.

The Grange

1 Ryerson Road, Warwick, N.Y.845-986-1170thegrangewarwick.wordpress.com

EXCELLENT

THE SPACE: Built in 1903, the brick building has a charm enhanced by a stream
rushing alongside it. At night the wood and brick interior seems to emanate its
own warm glow. If you are lucky, you may get a seat on the front porch. Seating
for 19.

THE CROWD: A mix, including farmers grabbing a pulled-pork sandwich, visitors
stopping by after shopping at nearby antique stores, couples on dates.

THE BAR: A small selection of mostly local alcoholic beverages; the most notable
we sampled were Warwick Valley Winery sangria, which was on tap, and Doc's Draft
hard ciders. For fans of cider, the pear version should not be missed.

THE BILL: Appetizers range from $7 to $11; entrees, $11 to $38. Desserts, $7.50.

WHAT WE LIKED: Tempura garlic scapes, miso and egg drop soup, Brittani's pâté,
capellini with dandelion greens and Parmigiano-Reggiano, roast pork with basmati
rice, hanger steak, onion rings and chocolate pot de crème.

IF YOU GO: Open Mondays and Thursdays, noon to 8 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays,
until 9 p.m.; Sundays, until 6 p.m. On-street parking. With just a few tables,
reservations are a good idea on weekend nights.

RATINGS: Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair, Poor

This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in
print.

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/26/nyregion/restaurant-review-the-grange-in-warwi
ck-true-farm-to-table.html

near what is known as the Black Dirt region. Top right, flat iron steak on a
pile of mashed potatoes with blue cheese from a local dairy farm. Above,
chocolate pot de crème. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY SUSAN STAVA FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

(89%); CHEESE (76%); FARMERS & RANCHERS (73%); INTERVIEWS (73%); JOB CREATION
(53%); ANTIQUE DEALERS (52%)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%)

                              Late Edition - Final

The Caribbean, Transplanted

BYLINE: By JOANNE STARKEY

SECTION: Section LI; Column 0; Metropolitan Desk; DINING | EAST HAMPTON; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 776 words


Winston's Bar & Grill in East Hampton is the opposite of the typical Hamptons
restaurant. Instead of offering a cool, airy, summery ambience, Winston's is
cozy, cluttered and rustic.

The décor is eclectic with wood-covered walls (some from old wine crates), wide
plank floors, two long leather banquettes, a large wooden barrel in the center
of the room holding pitchers of water, six chandeliers hanging from the ceiling,
and numerous shelves and rafters filled with conch shells, horseshoes and
photographs of local places and people.

The food here is also atypical. Not many East End restaurants offer jerk
chicken, curried goat or fried lobster. The Caribbean touches come from the chef
and owner, Winston Lyons, a native of Jamaica. He left Jamaica in 1993, and for
over 20 years worked in the kitchens of East Hampton restaurants like East
Hampton Point, East Hampton Grill, Bostwick's and Turtle Crossing before opening
his own place in May.

Winston's is open for breakfast, lunch and dinner seven days a week. ''I'm here
all the time,'' Mr. Lyons said in a phone interview after my visits. Members of
the staff take their cues from him. They are hard-working, friendly and
outgoing.

The best dish on the menu, and one I would make a special trip for, is the
grilled artichoke. It came in halves, crunchy with flavor. I also liked the
mussels steamed in white wine, shallots and garlic, which was served with two
slices of delicious bread from the grill perched on top. The contents of the
bread basket, filled with hard slices dry from reheating, would have benefited
from some time on the grill.

We liked the full-of-verve Manhattan clam chowder, but the fried oyster
appetizer was disappointing. It sounded great on paper: ''Crispy fried oysters
served with lemon guacamole on crostini.'' Alas, the oysters were overwhelmed by
their breading.

Salads got mixed notices: The citrus Caribbean salad with a promised pomegranate
vinaigrette had a dressing with no discernible pomegranate taste or much taste
of anything else. The mixed green house salad with a vibrant champagne
vinaigrette was a better bet.

We all loved the crispy fried lobster, which was covered in saltine cracker
crumbs and then fried. The meat inside was moist and sweet. During the meal,
bits of the savory coating would fall off and we would munch it separately,
which provided a nice contrast with the sweet lobster meat. The dish came with
matchsticks of fried plantains, which also accompanied the thick, juicy
cheeseburger.

Other hits were the penne pasta tossed in a light tomato sauce with shrimp and
small chunks of lobster; a special of crunchy soft-shell crabs atop a rough-cut
slaw of red cabbage and carrots; and a delicate offering of sautéed crab meat
served in the shell with a roasted garlic butter sauce. Jerk chicken was
appropriately spicy but dry.

For dessert, we tried a tangy Key lime pie, which was very good, but the
house-made desserts, like the warm bread pudding in a rum sauce dotted with
bananas and apples, and a moist shortcake with blueberries and strawberries,
were even better.

Mr. Lyons came out of the kitchen a few times each night and made the rounds,
welcoming first-time diners and thanking repeat customers for their patronage.
The entire staff, from the busboys to the hostess, makes Winston's one of the
warmest and friendliest restaurants around.

Winston's Bar & Grill

100 Montauk Highway, East Hampton631-267-5400winstonsds.com

Very Good

THE SPACE: Cozy, with a lot of wood. There is a dining room and another room
with a bar, with seating for 66 inside and for 24 outside. Restrooms are not
wheelchair accessible.

THE CROWD: Smiling couples and small groups, including families with children.
Friendly, attentive staff.

THE BAR: A separate room with seven bar stools and five high tables for two.
There are 24 bottles on the wine list ($21 to $45) and 10 by the glass ($8 to
$12).

THE BILL: Breakfast entrees are $8 to $17; lunch entrees are $12 to $24 and
dinner entrees are $18 to $43. Large lobsters cost more.

WHAT WE LIKED: Manhattan clam chowder, steamed mussels, grilled artichokes,
house salad, soft-shell crabs, sautéed crab meat, fried lobster, grilled
cheeseburger, penne with lobster and shrimp, Key lime pie, bread pudding, berry
shortcake.

IF YOU GO: Open for breakfast, Mondays through Saturdays, 8 to 11 a.m.; Sunday
brunch, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.; lunch, Mondays through Saturdays, 11:30 a.m. to 3
p.m.; dinner, Sundays through Thursdays, 5 to 10 p.m., Fridays and Saturdays,
until 11 p.m. Reservations are recommended. Ample parking in adjacent lot.

RATINGS: Excellent, Very Good, Good, Fair, Poor




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/26/nyregion/restaurant-review-a-caribbean-ambienc
e-at-winstons-bar-grill-in-east-hampton.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Winston Lyons, right, chef and owner of Winston's Bar & Grill in
East Hampton, makes the rounds in his cozy, rustic dining room, which stands out
in an area known for its sleek and airy restaurant décors. The menu includes
crispy fried lobster, far left, and grilled artichoke. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY GORDON M.
GRANT FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: RESTAURANT REVIEWS (91%); RESTAURANTS (90%); INTERVIEWS (66%)

COUNTRY: CARIBBEAN ISLANDS (90%)

                              Late Edition - Final

When Style, Not Size, Counts

BYLINE: By JULIE SATOW

SECTION: Section RE; Column 0; Real Estate Desk; BIG DEAL; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1218 words


With his venture Cocoon9, Christopher Burch -- the man behind the now-shuttered
clothing brand C. Wonder and the former husband of the fashion designer Tory
Burch -- hopes to prove that small, prefabricated spaces can be luxurious and
perfect for the Hamptons.

Such a space is the company's Cocoon Studio, a 480-square-foot prototype of a
prefabricated house that is now on view at the Southampton location of Mecox
Gardens, the home furnishings store.

The rectangular building, which ranges in price from $225,000 to $275,000,
features a wall of sliding floor-to-ceiling windows and white lacquered
cabinetry that conceals shelving, kitchen appliances and a Murphy bed.

''About four or five years ago, I started looking into this concept of really
cool houses that you could manufacture quickly,'' said Mr. Burch, via phone from
Nihiwatu, a resort on Sumba Island east of Bali that he bought in 2013. ''The
goal was to create a thoughtfully designed product that is simple and elegant
and can be used for many different functionalities.''

Lindsay Burn, of New Canaan, Conn., recently became Cocoon9's first client,
after spending the last two and a half years researching a design for a pool
house and home office to complement her midcentury modern home. She said the
Cocoon Studio ''far surpassed my expectations -- quality of materials and modern
details.''

Mr. Burch founded Cocoon9 with a childhood friend, Edwin Mahoney, several years
ago, with the aim of tackling the increasingly crowded field of luxury prefab
homebuilding.

Prefabricated houses, typically manufactured piecemeal as modules on an assembly
line and put together like Legos on the building site, are a growing industry.
And as their popularity has risen, they are shaking off the dowdy, uniform
styles they were once known for, and increasingly becoming a less expensive way
to execute stylish designs. Recent examples include those by the designer
Philippe Starck, who is building prefab houses near Paris, and that of Tim
Wright, who is a grandson of Frank Lloyd Wright and who lives in a prefab house
in Wisconsin. And Dwell, the home design magazine, offers its own branded prefab
houses.

Cocoon9 began when Mr. Burch asked a team of designers in Shanghai, where he has
an office, to come up with building concepts. He soon recruited Mr. Mahoney, a
third-generation homebuilder and the owner of  E. B. Mahoney Builders of Bryn
Mawr, Pa.

''Chris said, 'Look, I have this concept to create a plug-and-play home, what do
you think?' '' said Mr. Mahoney, who grew up in Bryn Mawr, near Mr. Burch's
childhood home in Wayne. ''It was so out of the norm for me, since I build
sticks and bricks, but he sent me over to China, and when I saw what he was
doing, I just had to put my toe in the water.''

The company, which has a factory in China and another in New Jersey, has so far
manufactured two prototypes: the one on display at Mecox Gardens, which will be
delivered to Ms. Burn and her husband, Spencer Grimes, a financier, after the
summer-long open house ends; and the Cocoon Cabin, the same size but with a
different floor plan, at Mr. Burch's Southampton home, where it serves as his
pool house and guest cottage.

Cocoon9 is selling three models, all built as single modules and designed so as
to be easily transportable by flatbed truck. Both the Cocoon Cabin and the
Cocoon Studio measure 12 by 40 feet and are similarly priced. The Cocoon Lite
20, at 8 by 20 feet, costs between $75,000 and $95,000. Made of steel that can
withstand winds of up to 150 miles an hour, they are insulated so as to require
minimal air-conditioning or heating. The houses also have several environmental
features, such as LED lighting and nontoxic materials.

Despite their contemporary, geometric shape, these buildings suit even the
traditional architecture of the Hamptons, ''where pitched roofs and cedar siding
are the norm,'' as a blog post on the Mecox Gardens website noted. The exterior
of the Cocoon Studio is a wood-plastic composite, while other models have
exteriors of carbon stranded bamboo siding. Cabinetry can come in several
finishes, including bamboo or a matte or glossy white lacquer, while flooring is
either cerused oak or vinyl with an oak grain. The fixtures can also be tailored
to taste, from Venetian bronze to brushed stainless steel, with bathrooms that
feature marble mosaic or glass tiles.

The houses, which take four months to manufacture, also feature distinctive
touches like 360-degree TVs that can swivel from one room to the next and
showers made of ''smart glass'' that changes from clear to opaque when in use.
Buyers must build their own foundations on which to attach the buildings, secure
the proper permits and connect the utilities themselves, the costs for which can
vary, but may add up to around $30,000, according to the company. A crane is
also needed, which can run an additional $10,000, while shipping costs can range
from $5,000 to as much as $40,000, depending on the state. Once the home
arrives, it can be hooked up in a matter of days.

For Ms. Burn, the style of the Cocoon Studio at Mecox Gardens matched her house,
designed by the architect John Black Lee, seamlessly. ''Our house has such a
clean look and we wanted to honor that architectural aesthetic,'' she said.

So far, Ms. Burn is Cocoon9's first and only client, but after the soft launch
at Mecox Gardens, interest is growing, according to the company. The hope is
that these buildings will not just adorn the backyards of expensive homes, but
that hotel developers will buy several buildings and install them along a beach
in the Caribbean, for example, to create a near-instant eco-resort.

''The idea is that it can be used a variety of ways, from a house on a quiet
beach for one person, or a combination of houses for a hotel or offices,'' Mr.
Burch said.

Greg McKenzie, the interior designer who outfitted the Mecox Gardens house,
added: ''It could even be for someone who is building a house, who can plop it
down on the property while they are building, and then turn around and use it as
a pool house. Quite frankly, even builders could use it as a construction
trailer and bring it with them from site to site. It is extremely flexible and
stylistically would work in any topography.''

Steven Chen, the company's lead architect, recently went to New Canaan to
conduct a site visit at Ms. Burn's home. ''I wanted to look at road access for
getting in the flatbed truck, and to discuss utilities and the foundation, and
how to coordinate before the unit arrives,'' Mr. Chen said.

Cocoon9 hopes to stand out from the pack with its reach and its speed. ''We
surveyed our competition, and they are very regional, usually selling within a
300- to 500-mile radius of their plants,'' Mr. Mahoney said. ''They are building
their homes in sections that they then have to assemble. By the time you walk
into the company, order it and get it built, it is a 12- to 16-month cycle.''

Cocoon9 is offering smaller houses that can be built quickly and delivered
worldwide. ''We are 'plug and play' -- if you order it tomorrow you will see it
in less than 16 weeks,'' Mr. Mahoney said. ''It's hard to beat that.''

For weekly email updates on residential real estate news, sign up here. Follow
us on Twitter: @nytrealestate.

A Temporary Civilization

BYLINE: By BRIAN SCHAEFER

SECTION: Section AR; Column 0; Arts and Leisure Desk; DANCE; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 174 words


The beauty of ancient sites lies partly in their decay. We call them ''ruins''
with affection; it's the pillar intact and the pillar crumbled, side by side,
that tell a compelling story. The multidisciplinary dance artist Walter
Dundervill is something of an archaeologist of self-made worlds where grace sits
at the edge of destruction. He layers historical references on top of one
another, places them in colorful, immersive environments of his own design and
populates them with splendidly clad characters. Then he starts excavating.

Mr. Dundervill's three-hour dance installation ''Arena'' had its premiere last
July at Jack, the young, experimental arts space in Brooklyn, and returns for an
encore Thursday through Saturday. The show is come and go as you please, so it
can be an appetizer to the evening (arrive early for extravagant Louis XIV
gowns) or digestif (come late to catch the climax) or, better yet, stay
throughout and experience the full arc of this wonderfully mysterious temporary
civilization. (6 to 9 p.m., jackny.org.)



URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/26/arts/dance/arena-builds-and-crumbles-a-tempora
ry-civilization-through-dance.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTO: Walter Dundervill's ''Arena'' is a three-hour installation at
Jack. (PHOTOGRAPH BY MARIA BARANOVA)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: ANTHROPOLOGY & ARCHAEOLOGY (78%); ARCHAEOLOGY (78%); DANCERS (72%)

LOAD-DATE: July 26, 2015

Corrections

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 98 words


An article last Sunday about the early travails of the New Horizons mission to
Pluto referred incorrectly to the volcanic eruption on Jupiter's moon Io that
the spacecraft observed in 2007. Erupting volcanoes on Io were seen during
earlier NASA missions; the New Horizons images were not the first. And because
of an editing error, an accompanying picture caption misstated the date and
location of a spin test of the spacecraft before its launching. The test shown
took place in 2005 at the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland, not in
2006 at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

Sloane Crosley

BYLINE: By SLOANE CROSLEY.

Sloane Crosley is the author of two essay collections. Her first novel, ''The
Clasp,'' will be published in October.

SECTION: Section AR; Column 0; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 272 words


Who's mad at me and how mad are they? I've never made it through a reading
without being asked that question. This is the world we live in -- you write
narrative nonfiction and people assume you've exaggerated everything; you write
fiction and people assume you've swiped it from reality. So things on tour have
always gotten pretty personal.

Amid the book-related questions, I've been asked to call someone's mother for
them, when to reach out to an estranged friend, if I can hook them up with an
apartment in Manhattan, if I can get them in touch with David Sedaris, my
darkest secret, tips for overcoming depression, when malaria pills expire, how
about just David Sedaris's email then, if they paid too much for this dress, if
I want to get married, if I think they should get married. I don't mind.

Like most authors, I've read to rooms of 10 people, two of whom realized they
were at the wrong reading and left halfway through. It's good fortune to have a
crowd. I just wished people knew they were asking advice from someone who woke
up before dawn in Miami, flew to Austin for morning TV, changed in the station
bathroom, whacked her head on the corner of a tampon dispenser and bled,
quietly, in front of a local magician. Though, thanks to a book tour, I can also
say I'm someone who's handed her driver's license to a T.S.A. agent in Madison
and been told I made her laugh when she needed it.

In a few months I will go on tour again, to bleed for a novel this time. I will
miss the old questions. Perhaps some of them will make an appearance. And in the
meantime? That dress was totally worth it. It looks great on you.




URL:

GRAPHIC: PHOTO (PHOTOGRAPH BY CAITLIN MITCHELL)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

SUBJECT: NOVELS & SHORT STORIES (78%); WRITERS (77%); FICTION LITERATURE (77%);
NON FICTION LITERATURE (72%); MALARIA (54%)

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (56%)

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (56%)

One-Bedrooms That Stretch

BYLINE: By MICHELLE HIGGINS

SECTION: Section RE; Column 0; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1698 words


Can't find a decent two-bedroom at a price you can afford? Try searching for a
one-bedroom big enough to turn into two.

That's what some buyers are doing as soaring prices and a scarcity of listings
in New York City make it tough to jump to the next apartment size up.

Plus-size one-bedrooms -- the kind that would allow, say, a couple expecting a
baby to put up a wall to create another bedroom -- are increasingly
sought-after, brokers say, as less expensive alternatives to existing
two-bedrooms. Large one-bedrooms with separate dining areas, known as Junior 4s,
are in especially hot demand as the dining nook can easily be converted to a
nursery or home office.

''Those attract a lot more attention,'' said Stephen Geller, an associate broker
at the Corcoran Group who has listed three Junior 4s in the past few months.
''They moved much more quickly than ''straight one-bedrooms,'' he said, and
received ''twice as much traffic,'' especially from younger couples entering the
market who don't want to have to move again in a year or two if their families
expand.

Lisa and Matt Lombardi, both in their 30s, who were married in 2012, were living
in a one-bedroom in the Bronx owned by Mr. Lombardi's father. After saving
enough for a down payment on a place of their own, and with plans to start a
family, the couple had hopes of finding a two-bedroom for around $600,000 in
brownstone Brooklyn.

''I had naïvely thought maybe we could get more bang for our buck out there,''
as opposed to Manhattan, said Ms. Lombardi, who works in development and the
commercialization of scientific discoveries at Mount Sinai Innovation Partners.
''The reality was a lot of people were more attractive purchasers,'' she said,
recalling how fierce the competition was even for tiny two-bedrooms. ''We'd go
to an open house; the line would be out the door and people were almost rolling
in bags of cash for the apartment.''

So when Jimmi Circosta, an associate broker at Citi Habitats, suggested they
consider large one-bedrooms in Manhattan, the couple were game. In 2013, they
bought a place in Yorkville, paying $500,000 for an 850-square-foot one-bedroom
-- bigger than some of the two-bedrooms they had visited in Brooklyn with higher
price tags. The apartment had a large living room and a dining nook. They spent
about a year updating the place, which, besides turning the nook into an
8-by-8-square-foot nursery with a sliding opaque glass door, included redoing
the kitchen and upgrading the bathroom. They moved in last October. Luca, their
son, arrived in March of this year.

Because his room lacks a window, the apartment can't be sold as a legal
two-bedroom. But when it comes time to sell, Ms. Lombardi said, ''I know the
reality is New Yorkers will look at it and see it as a two-bedroom.''

Out-of-towners tend to have a more difficult time with the idea of putting an
infant in the equivalent of what would be a walk-in closet in many parts of the
United States. Jamie Fedorko, a salesman at Warburg Realty, who was born and
raised in New York City, recently showed a Junior 4 to a client from Florida
with plans to start a family down the road.

''She couldn't get her mind around it,'' he said. ''I can't tell you how many
people I know who grew up in what was essentially the dining room. For us, it's
normal.'' He added, ''We all survived.''

Raising children in the dining room may not seem like the American dream of
homeownership. But in New York City's tight real estate market, the reconfigured
one-bedroom may be a way for buyers to move up, if only a half-step.

''I see it as pragmatism setting in,'' said Jonathan J. Miller, the president of
the appraisal firm Miller Samuel, noting that the price gap between one- and
two-bedrooms in Manhattan is larger than ever. The spread between the median
sales price, which measures the middle of the market, of one-bedrooms ($750,000)
and two-bedrooms ($1,725,000) grew by 42 percent to $975,000 in the second
quarter, from $685,000 just two years ago. As that gulf widens, these
''tweener'' apartments, as Mr. Miller calls them, ''put salve on the wound of
affordability,'' he said.

Katherine Tsang has lived in small apartments most of her life. ''In a sense,
it's what I'm comfortable with,'' said Ms. Tsang, who works in marketing and
grew up in Hong Kong, where, as she puts it, ''every inch matters.''

In 2013, she and her husband upgraded from the rental studio in Midtown
Manhattan that they had shared for four years to a one-bedroom in the same
building. When their son, Massimo, arrived two years ago, he slept behind a
partition in a corner of the bedroom while the couple searched for an apartment
to buy. With a budget of about $750,000, they focused on large one-bedrooms.

''We were trying to find creative ways to parse out a room,'' Ms. Tsang said.
But conceptualizing exactly where a wall might go and how Massimo's expanding
collection of baby gear would fit inside was tricky. ''Sometimes we would have
printouts of floor plans that looked like they were convertible,'' she said,
''but we'd show up and they were not, or it was not what it seemed on paper.''

Then, Naomi J. Davis, an associate broker at Brown Harris Stevens, showed the
couple a one-bedroom on the Upper East Side with a dining area-turned-nursery.

''Because a child was already living there, I was able to see how toys and a
little activity table and a big-boy bed would fit. It gave me a great
visualization of what could be,'' Ms. Tsang said. She and her husband bought the
apartment for less than the listed price of $699,000, which left them money for
renovations.

With the nursery already in place, the couple worked with an architect to
optimize the space in the rest of the apartment. They swapped out the French
doors separating the living room and the nursery for wood doors to create more
privacy. The master bedroom now has a larger closet and an office nook with
bookshelves. In the kitchen, the renovation created a pantry, and a place was
even found for a washer/dryer.

''It was a very clever use of space,'' Ms. Davis said. ''The renovation has
given them exactly what they need.''

It's not just young families who are considering large one-bedrooms.

Mr. Circosta of Citi Habitats worked with a couple in their 60s who bought a
Junior 4 on the Upper East Side for about $700,000 after moving from a townhouse
in Queens. The couple, however, undid a conversion. ''The sellers had a wall up
for a small home office,'' Mr. Circosta said. His clients removed the wall to
create a more open space.

Investors also sometimes take the step of converting a one-bedroom to a two.

When the one-bedroom next door to the home of Arrun Kapoor, 40, and Sarah
Rasheed, 36, hit the market in February for about $1 million, the couple
scrambled to come up with a down payment. But they didn't want it for
themselves: They saw its potential as a two-bedroom to rent to somebody else.
With a two-bedroom, Mr. Kapoor said, ''We can get more per square foot.''

Mr. Kapoor, who works for a social impact venture capital fund, had been eyeing
his neighbors' apartment since he purchased his home, a two-bedroom on the edge
of Fort Greene, Brooklyn, for $569,000 five years ago. Since then, the place has
doubled in value to about $1.2 million, enabling the couple to secure most of
the down payment for the one-bedroom next door through cash-out refinancing.

The couple, who have a 2-year-old son, plan to someday use their acquisition to
enlarge their home. ''We will take the wall down as soon as we are financially
capable,'' said Ms. Rasheed, a lawyer.

''It would be a very interesting combination,'' said Shakti C'Ganti, an
associate broker with the Corcoran Group, who represented the seller.

Jen Genel and her husband were living in a one-bedroom of around 800 square feet
in Midtown East when they started talking about having children about three
years ago. ''We knew we wanted to have a family and knew the suburbs weren't for
us,'' said Ms. Genel, who grew up on Long Island. With a budget of $1.3 million,
the couple began hunting for a two-bedroom in brownstone Brooklyn. But what they
found at that price either involved a significant renovation or was snapped up
by a buyer who offered more cash.

Their search took on new urgency in February 2013, when Ms. Genel found out she
was pregnant with twins. The couple abandoned the two-bedroom idea and began
searching in terms of pure space.

''We had a gauge of how much square footage we needed to live comfortably,'' Ms.
Genel said. ''Anything over 1,200 would have been O.K. for us.''

In August, they saw a listing for a 1,216-square-foot one-bedroom for about $1.1
million at One Brooklyn Bridge Park, Brooklyn Heights, that was advertised as a
''convertible two-bedroom.'' The listing came with a couple of floor plans that
suggested where a wall could be installed to create another bedroom.

''My husband and I ran in immediately,'' said Ms. Genel, who liked the
apartment's oversize windows, high ceilings and loft-like feel. After speaking
with a contractor to be sure the work was feasible, they put in a bid for $1.085
million, which was accepted. Then they hired an architect who made a second
bedroom out of a portion of the living room, an office area and a sliver of the
master bedroom, stealing a window from the wall of glass in the living room. The
couple also added a shower to a half bath.

Even with the renovations, Ms. Genel said, they were able to remain below their
$1.3 million budget. However, timing was not on their side. The twins arrived
before the work was completed and after they had sold their place in Manhattan.
For seven months, the four squeezed into a studio on Long Island owned by Ms.
Genel's father.

Last May they moved into their reconfigured two-bedroom, two-bath. ''We love
it,'' said Ms. Genel, who has a blog about raising twins called Goingtwinsane.
''It's really a great place for this stage in our life.''

Now that the twins, Jake and Rachel, are 20 months old and beginning to toddle
around, the couple are starting to talk about their next project: turning the
foyer into a mini mudroom.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/26/realestate/making-more-space-in-a-one-bedroom-
apartment.html

GRAPHIC: PHOTOS: Lisa and Matt Lombardi with their son, Luca, in their
one-bedroom apartment on the Upper East Side. They used sliding glass doors to
turn the dining nook into a room for the baby. (RE1)
Above, another view of Lisa and Matt Lombardi's renovation, which turned a
one-bedroom into a two-bedroom. Top right, Arrun Kapoor and Sarah Rasheed at
home with Sufyan, 2, and top left, in the one-bedroom next door they bought to
convert into a two-bedroom rental. Someday, they plan to combine the two
apartments into one.
 Katherine Tsang and her husband bought an Upper East Side one-bedroom with a
dining area-turned-nursery already in place for Massimo, now 2. Subsequent
renovations improved the use of space, creating an office nook and a large
closet in the master bedroom, and a shoe-changing station in the foyer, among
other things. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY JOSHUA BRIGHT FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES) (RE10)

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               The New York Times

                              July 26, 2015 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

Start by Working Beyond Your Résumé

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT.

Each week, Adam Bryant talks with top executives about the challenges of leading
and managing. Follow him on Twitter: @nytcorneroffice.

SECTION: Section BU; Column 0; Money and Business/Financial Desk; CORNER OFFICE;
Pg. 2

LENGTH: 919 words


This interview with David Politis, chief executive of BetterCloud, a maker of
cloud-based software, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

Q. Were you in leadership roles as a boy?

A. My first real leadership experience was with taekwondo. I got my black belt
when I was 12 and started teaching some of the classes, with people of all ages.
I enjoyed it.

How have your parents influenced you?

My drive really comes from watching my father as I was growing up. He's an
entrepreneur and had a lot of different businesses, including real estate
development in Harlem and the South Bronx, and project finance in emerging
markets like West Africa. Because he was working so much and traveling so much,
he often would take me with him. From the age of 8, I have memories of going to
Harlem and going to building sites. He taught a real estate class at N.Y.U., and
he would take me to the class when I was 9 years old, give me a pad of paper and
say, ''Just take notes.''

When I got to high school, he was doing work in the former Soviet Union. He took
me to Lithuania and Ukraine. In college, he was blind-copying me on almost every
email he sent for work. I knew about what he was working on, and I would ask him
about his different projects.

The thing he would say most often is that you can do anything you put your mind
to. Because of some early successes, like getting my black belt at a very young
age, I found he was right. I always remind myself that if I have enough
discipline and work ethic, I will achieve what I want to achieve.

And tell me about your mother.

She's a gynecologist and worked most of her career at Planned Parenthood. She
would bring me to work, too, if I had a day off from school, and I would sit at
the front desk and check people in for appointments. She had a real connection
with her patients. With both my parents, they were the same person at work as
they were at home.

What did you do after college?

After I graduated, I started working at a small start-up with about 15 people.
It didn't do very well. And so six months into my first job out of school, every
person in the company was fired, literally, except for me. The two founders, who
had made a lot of money with an earlier company, came to me and said, ''Dave,
there's about $600,000 left in the bank. Do you want to be C.E.O.?'' And I said,
''Uh, sure. Why not?''

We pivoted the company, and over the next six years we actually built up the
business to 150 people or so before we sold it. I learned everything -- hiring,
firing, sales, marketing, customer support, financing.

Tell me about the culture of your current company, which you started four years
ago.

There are a number of things we do. In terms of transparency, I share everything
I can with the whole company. And when we discuss it during company meetings,
everyone can submit questions beforehand anonymously, and I'll answer them. We
also send monthly emails that explain what every department is working on that
month, and what they achieved the month before.

I'm also a big believer in giving people ownership of certain areas in the
business. It's amazing what happens when you do that. People want to make a
difference, and when you give them an area of the business that they can affect,
the amount of stuff that gets done, and the pride in their work is amazing.
People make mistakes, but they learn from them and they continue to improve.

How do you hire?

My job in the interview process is to really understand the person, what they're
looking to do in their career, and understand if we're going to be a good fit
for them. In many cases, I try to dissuade them from taking the job. I try to be
as honest as I can about the bad parts of the job and the high expectations.
People have decided against taking jobs after interviewing with me.

What are your best questions?

I always ask, ''What would be your dream job if you could do anything in the
world?'' My next question is, ''Why aren't you doing that?'' Those two questions
will tell you a lot about people's passions and their fears.

The other ones I ask are, ''What do you love every day when you go to work, and
what do you hate?'' Sometimes people are interviewing for a job, but they'll
never get to do what they love in that job.

What advice do you give to new college grads?

The first thing I tell people is, try to go where you can be a big fish in a
small pond. Whether it's a company or a market, go where you can actually have a
real impact on the business. That gives you an opportunity to punch above your
weight class or take on more responsibility than your résumé warrants. You may
get paid less, but the experience and probably the enjoyment are going to be
much higher.

The second thing is that when you go into a company, especially right out of
college, you have a certain energy to be in that first job. You're ready to
work. But I think a lot of people's excitement can get dulled by colleagues
who've been in those companies for a while. You get lulled into the cadence that
everybody else is in.

So I tell people to keep that energy, keep that excitement, keep that passion
that you have in the beginning. Keep the work ethic up and don't get stuck in
this regular cadence of ''This is what I need to do in order to get my job
done.'' Do more than that. Just keep pushing that envelope. People will look at
you like you're crazy and you're making them look bad. But my advice is to just
keep pushing through because that's how you will stand out.




URL:
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/26/business/david-politis-of-bettercloud-start-by
-working-beyond-your-resume.html

cloud-based software (PHOTOGRAPH BY EARL WILSON/THE NEW YORK TIMES)

Readers Respond to Divorce

SECTION: Section ST; Column 0; Style Desk; COMMENTS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 460 words


Readers responded to ''Divorced, but Not From Life,'' an article by Penelope
Green from Sunday Styles. Below is a selection of comments from
nytimes.com/styles, edited for space.

The chances of a divorce are high as time progresses. Reality often is that
being with the same person for an extended period of time, while each changes,
is difficult for both parties. Prenuptial agreements should be mandatory, and
then sensible people should keep them updated. Of course, many feel that having
a prenup shows a lack of commitment. A sound legal agreement can save a lot of
problems. In the end, what are most important are financial issues.

Dan Green, Palm Beach, Fla.

Not everyone in need or want of a divorce lives in an expensive carriage house
and has affluent friends. In 1978 in California, I barely had enough income to
cover rent, food for four and car upkeep. I called the Legal Aid Society. They
were perceptive and well informed, were interested in my situation, gave great
advice and were encouraging. I negotiated directly with my husband, carefully
read and edited the legal papers and paid nothing to get my divorce. Hooray for
the Legal Aid Society!

Nativetex, Houston

Much time is spent lamenting divorce and recovering from the experience of
divorce, when it was the marriage that housed problems. Divorce is a solution.
Our expectations of marriage are far outside human reality. If one remains angry
and resentful of a former spouse, one may as well have stayed married and
retained the unhappy union.

People evolve, grow, change and come to own an identity, one that may no longer
be compatible. Accepting that our expectations will not always be met,
especially by others, is a good first step in moving forward. Understanding that
we change, and others change, is paramount to outgrowing childishness.

Make the divorce easier than the messy marriage. Divide the assets fairly and
allow yourself to create a future where you succeed on your own merits; be kind
to the former spouse, especially if the marriage produced children. You will
never regret this.

Faith, Ohio

Divorce is traumatic for both parties, but based on my experience, women have
generally far more support from female friends than men get from their male
friends.

When I was getting divorced 30 years ago, my wife's divorced friends gathered to
give her advice about how to take me to the cleaners and use custody of our
child to get more money and concessions out of me, whereas my friends were a lot
more about, ''Hey, man, too bad about the split. Did you see that game last
night?''

Divorce and especially custody arrangements are still wildly skewed in the
woman's favor in many if not most cases in the United States. That is simply a
fact.

DD, Los Angeles

Comments

SECTION: Section TR; Column 0; Travel Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 762 words


Our cover article last Sunday (''Storm Clouds Over the Smith,'' by Christopher
Solomon) about a trip down the Smith River in Montana, which is imperiled by a
proposed copper mine, elicited many responses from readers, nearly all concerned
about the proposal and what it would mean for the river and the region. Here is
a selection. (Comments have been edited for clarity and space.)

At Stake in Montana

The issues are fairly simple. The mine owners and operators keep saying ''trust
us,'' and year after year they break that trust. Second, regardless of what
anyone says about remediation or restoration, it is not the same. It took
millenniums for areas like the Smith to become one of the special places. Only
man is foolish enough and has the hubris to think that they could return it to
its original condition if they despoil it.

Tom, Midwest

All one needs to do is to take a trip to Anaconda or Butte if one wishes to see
what the results of mining are. While Butte was at one time considered the
richest city in the United States, it is a shadow of its former self. You can
see the remains of the Anaconda operation for miles, a black pile of waste on
which nothing grows. Better we reuse all the copper already mined.

doktorij, Eastern Tennessee

I grew up in Great Falls, Mont., and spent my summers in the Little Belt
mountains just north of the Smith River. In the late '60s, after finding toxic
amounts of arsenic, a significant byproduct of gold and copper mining, in our
water, we had to divest ourselves of our land for a fraction of what we'd paid
for it. Mining companies have been raping this pristine place for many decades;
there is no reason to believe they would behave any differently now.

mrmerrill, Portland, Ore.

How much more environmental devastation will be wrought in the name of economic
development? Is it beyond our imagination and ingenuity to find other means of
job creation? Must we destroy a pristine wilderness area to create 200 jobs? It
borders on criminal. It borders on insane.

thebigmancat, New York

My family has vacationed, winter and summer, in Montana for decades. Montana's
value lies in the fact that it is a beautiful and wild place, not in the
minerals below its surface. History shows that the value of the minerals goes to
the owners while the cost of cleaning up environmental destruction goes to the
taxpayers, both state and federal. The only way to ensure that nothing happens
to this magnificent river is to not mine copper next to it.

JP Tolins, Minneapolis

I own land in the Smith River Canyon. It is the most beautiful place I have ever
been. I cannot believe that it will be destroyed for a copper deposit with an
economic life of all of 13 years, and will directly employ 30 people in the
White Sulphur Springs/Meagher County area.

Yes, we need copper and other minerals. But there are many other places where
copper is abundant and is presently mined, and where the environment has already
been ruined. A copper mine in the Smith watershed is just an insult to one of
the world's most beautiful spots.

Bob Carl, Marietta, Ga.

As a Montana native, I've had the privilege of floating this river perhaps a
dozen times over two decades. The short-term wealth that copper might bring
shouldn't trump the long-term sanctity of this river. Montana has fallen prey to
outside promises of prosperity and security far too many times, only to see
those promises broken, the foreign interests having fled, and our waters made
toxic (see Silver Bow Creek, Blackfoot River, Belt Creek, Clark Fork River and
many, many more.) Mr. Solomon's final words say it best -- ''Nothing must happen
to this place.''

T Bulger, Montana

Can the river survive? This is the kind of question a lack of regulation and
ignorance about ecosystems and the natural world result in. Did the Hudson River
survive heavy metal and PCB contamination? Has the Gulf survived the assaults of
BP and thousands of abandoned wells? Has ''coal country'' survived strip and
mountain top removal mining? You can still find these places on a map, but they
are ghosts of what they once were.

gregory, Dutchess County, N.Y.

Has no one else read that this proposed mine is on privately owned mining claims
and ranches?

Mark, Montana

The public good always supersedes the uses allowed on private property. You may
own your city lot, free and clear, but you may not be allowed to raise pigs on
it, for example. Most of our environmental problems come from ignoring this
fundamental precept of a decent society.

Jerry Attrich, Port Townsend, Wash.
